7.meaning_en: The ceremony of crowning a sovereign.
usage_sentences: The prince's coronation was a grand event attended by dignitaries from around the world.
The crown jewels are displayed to the public except during a coronation.

7.meaning_en: A collection of written texts; the main body of something.
usage_sentences: The linguist analyzed a large corpus of text messages to study modern language use.
The main corpus of his argument was presented in the first chapter.

7.meaning_en: Confirm or give support to (a statement, theory, or finding).
usage_sentences: The second witness was able to corroborate the victim's account of the incident.
Further research is needed to corroborate his theory.

7.meaning_en: A solemn procession, especially for a funeral.
usage_sentences: A long cortege followed the hearse to the cemetery.
The presidential cortege moved slowly through the city streets.

7.meaning_en: Two lines of verse, usually in the same meter and joined by rhyme.
usage_sentences: Many of Shakespeare's sonnets end with a rhyming couplet.
The poet used a simple couplet to express a profound idea.
7.origin: From Old French, diminutive of 'couple' (a pair).

7.meaning_en: A person whose job is to look after cattle.
usage_sentences: The young cowherd led the herd of cattle to the pasture.
In many traditional stories, the main character is a humble cowherd.
7.origin: From 'cow' + 'herd' (in the sense of a herdsman).

7.meaning_en: Able to be believed; convincing.
usage_sentences: The journalist cited several credible sources in her article.
Her story was so strange that it was hardly credible.

7.meaning_en: Having or showing too great a readiness to believe things; gullible.
7.meaning_hi: आसानी से विश्वास करने वाला; भोला
usage_sentences: The credulous tourist was easily tricked by the street scammer.
He told a tall tale, and only the most credulous people believed him.

7.meaning_en: A system of religious belief; a faith; a set of guiding principles.
usage_sentences: The organization welcomes people of every race, color, and creed.
His personal creed was to always treat others with kindness.

7.meaning_en: A place where a dead person's body is cremated.
usage_sentences: After the funeral service, the body was taken to the crematorium.
The crematorium is located next to the cemetery.

7.meaning_en: Cause someone to become unable to walk; cause severe damage to.
7.meaning_hi: अपंग बना देना; पंगु कर देना
usage_sentences: The severe injury threatened to cripple the athlete's career.
A lack of funding could cripple the entire research project.
7.origin: From Old English 'crypel', of Germanic origin.

7.meaning_en: The deep hoarse sound made by a frog or raven; to speak in a hoarse voice.
usage_sentences: We could hear the frogs begin to croak as evening fell.
With a sore throat, he could only croak out a few words.

7.meaning_en: Break or fall apart into small fragments, especially as part of deterioration.
usage_sentences: The ancient castle walls have started to crumble over time.
She crumbled the cheese over the top of the salad.
7.origin: From an Old English word related to 'crumb'.

7.meaning_en: An energetic campaign for a social, political, or religious cause.
usage_sentences: She led a lifelong crusade for women's right to vote.
The organization launched a crusade to end child poverty.

7.meaning_en: Something written in cipher or code.
usage_sentences: The spy sent a message written in a complex cryptograph.
Historians are still trying to decipher the ancient cryptograph.

7.meaning_en: A keeper or custodian of a museum or other collection.
usage_sentences: The curator of the art museum carefully planned the new exhibition.
As the curator, she was responsible for acquiring new pieces for the collection.
7.origin: From Latin 'curator', from 'curare' (to take care of).

7.meaning_en: A person who believes people are motivated by self-interest; one who questions sincerity.
usage_sentences: He is such a cynic that he questions the motive behind every act of kindness.
Don't be a cynic; some people genuinely want to help.
7.origin: From Greek 'kunikos', meaning 'dog-like', after a school of philosophy.

7.meaning_en: Extreme or irrational fear of dogs.
usage_sentences: Her cynophobia was so severe that she would cross the street to avoid even a small dog.
He developed cynophobia after being bitten by a dog as a child.

7.meaning_en: A person or thing that is the centre of attention or admiration.
usage_sentences: The bride, in her beautiful gown, was the cynosure of all eyes.
The new skyscraper quickly became the cynosure of the city's skyline.
7.origin: From Greek 'kunusoura' (dog's tail), a name for the constellation Ursa Minor, which contains the Pole Star.

7.meaning_en: A secret or disguised way of writing; a code.
usage_sentences: The secret message was written in a complex cypher that was difficult to break.
The spies communicated using a cypher to protect their information.

7.meaning_en: The branch of biology concerned with the structure and function of cells.
usage_sentences: Cytology is a vital field for cancer research and diagnosis.
The lab technician specialized in cytology, analyzing cell samples under a microscope.

7.meaning_en: Minor crime, especially that committed by young people.
usage_sentences: The community center started a program to combat juvenile delinquency.
Poverty and lack of opportunity can be contributing factors to delinquency.
7.origin: From Latin 'delinquere', meaning 'to fail in one's duty'.

7.meaning_en: A young person tending to commit minor crime; failing in duty.
usage_sentences: The court ordered the young delinquent to perform community service.
He was delinquent in paying his taxes and received a penalty.
7.origin: From Latin 'delinquens', from 'delinquere' (to fail in one's duty).

7.meaning_en: Become liquid by absorbing moisture from the air.
usage_sentences: Certain chemical salts will deliquesce if they are not stored in an airtight container.
We watched the crystal begin to deliquesce in the humid air.

7.meaning_en: An acutely disturbed state of mind with restlessness, illusions, and incoherence.
usage_sentences: The patient's high fever caused him to fall into a state of delirium.
In his delirium, he was hallucinating and talking nonsense.

7.meaning_en: A political leader who seeks support by appealing to popular desires and prejudices.
usage_sentences: The notorious demagogue used fear and lies to gain power.
A true leader appeals to reason, whereas a demagogue appeals to emotion.

7.meaning_en: The study of statistics relating to the changing structure of human populations.
usage_sentences: The study of demography helps governments plan for the future needs of their citizens.
She is a professor of demography, specializing in population aging.

7.meaning_en: Criticize unfairly; disparage; belittle.
usage_sentences: There is no need to denigrate the efforts of others, even if you disagree with them.
The campaign was marked by attempts to denigrate the opponent's character.

7.meaning_en: An inhabitant or occupant of a particular place.
usage_sentences: The fish and other denizens of the deep sea are fascinating creatures.
He was a well-known denizen of the local pub.

7.meaning_en: A person who makes a deposition or affidavit under oath.
usage_sentences: The deponent provided a sworn statement to the court.
During the deposition, the lawyer questioned the deponent for several hours.
7.origin: From Latin 'deponere', meaning 'to put down, testify'.

7.meaning_en: Morally corrupt; wicked; perverted.
usage_sentences: The movie was about a depraved killer with no sense of remorse.
He was shocked by the depraved acts of cruelty he witnessed.
7.origin: From the verb 'deprave', from Latin 'depravare' (to pervert).

7.meaning_en: Express disapproval of; disparage; belittle.
usage_sentences: He would always self-deprecate, making jokes about his own shortcomings.
The teacher deprecated the use of slang in formal essays.

7.meaning_en: Mad; insane.
usage_sentences: His grief had left him emotionally deranged.
Only a deranged mind could be capable of such a horrific crime.
7.origin: From the verb 'derange', from French 'déranger' (to disturb).

7.meaning_en: In a very poor condition due to disuse and neglect.
usage_sentences: The children loved to explore the old, derelict mansion.
The city has a plan to renovate the derelict warehouses by the waterfront.

7.meaning_en: The state of having been abandoned; shameful failure to fulfil obligations.
usage_sentences: The soldier was charged with dereliction of duty for abandoning his post.
The historic building had fallen into a state of dereliction.

7.meaning_en: Express contempt for; ridicule; mock (in a cruel way).
usage_sentences: The other children would often deride him for his unusual accent.
Critics derided the artist's new work as childish and meaningless.

8.meaning_en: The action of deserting a person, cause, or organization.
usage_sentences: The desertion of his family was a cowardly act.
A soldier found guilty of desertion during wartime can face severe punishment.
8.origin: From the verb 'desert', from Latin 'deserere' (to abandon).

8.meaning_en: A state of low spirits caused by loss of hope or courage.
usage_sentences: A deep sense of despondency fell over the team after their fourth consecutive loss.
He was in a state of despondency after failing his final exams.

8.meaning_en: Discourage (someone) from doing something by instilling fear of the consequences.
usage_sentences: The presence of security cameras should deter criminals.
Don't let the fear of failure deter you from pursuing your dreams.

8.meaning_en: The action of discouraging an action through instilling fear of the consequences.
usage_sentences: The country's nuclear arsenal was meant to serve as a deterrence against attack.
The threat of a large fine is an effective deterrence to illegal parking.

8.meaning_en: Showing skilful use of underhand tactics to achieve goals; (of a route) indirect.
usage_sentences: He used devious methods to get the promotion he wanted.
We took a devious path through the woods to avoid the main road.

8.meaning_en: A particular form of a language peculiar to a specific region or social group.
usage_sentences: The characters in the book spoke with a thick Scottish dialect.
Although they both spoke Italian, their regional dialects were very different.

8.meaning_en: A forceful and bitter verbal attack against someone or something.
usage_sentences: The angry citizen launched into a long diatribe against the city council.
His article was a furious diatribe against the new government policy.
8.origin: From Greek 'diatribē', meaning 'a spending of time, discourse'.

8.meaning_en: A person who cultivates an area of interest without real commitment or knowledge.
usage_sentences: He was a dilettante who dabbled in painting, writing, and music but mastered none of them.
She was no dilettante; she had studied the subject for years.

8.meaning_en: Having or showing care and conscientiousness in one's work or duties.
usage_sentences: The diligent student always completed her homework and studied hard for exams.
He was a diligent worker, respected by all his colleagues.

8.meaning_en: Alcoholism, specifically an uncontrollable craving for alcoholic drinks.
usage_sentences: He checked into a rehabilitation center to get help for his dipsomania.
Dipsomania is a serious condition that can destroy a person's life.

8.meaning_en: A book listing individuals or organizations alphabetically with details like addresses and phone numbers.
usage_sentences: I looked up the company's address in the online business directory.
The phone directory for the entire city was a very thick book.

8.meaning_en: A lament for the dead, especially one forming part of a funeral rite.
usage_sentences: The funeral procession moved slowly to the sound of a mournful dirge.
The poem was a sorrowful dirge for a fallen hero.
8.origin: From the Latin 'Dirige', the first word of an antiphon in the Office for the Dead.

8.meaning_en: An illogical or surprising lack of compatibility or similarity between two or more facts.
usage_sentences: There was a significant discrepancy between his story and the evidence.
The accountant found a discrepancy in the financial records.
8.origin: From Latin 'discrepantia', from 'discrepare' (to differ in sound).

8.meaning_en: A heavy thick-centred disc thrown by an athlete in competition.
usage_sentences: The Olympic athlete threw the discus over 70 meters.
The discus is one of the oldest events in track and field.

8.meaning_en: Deprive (someone) of the right to vote.
usage_sentences: Literacy tests were once used to disenfranchise minority voters.
The new law threatened to disenfranchise thousands of citizens.
8.origin: From 'dis-' (not) + 'enfranchise' (to grant the right to vote).

8.meaning_en: The state of being deprived of a right or privilege, especially the right to vote.
usage_sentences: Activists have long fought against the disenfranchisement of marginalized communities.
The poll tax was a tool of voter disenfranchisement.

8.meaning_en: Angry or dissatisfied; discontented.
usage_sentences: A group of disgruntled employees staged a protest over their low wages.
The customer wrote a disgruntled review after receiving poor service.

8.meaning_en: Depressing; dreary; pitifully or disgracefully bad.
usage_sentences: The rainy, grey weather made for a dismal afternoon.
The team's performance in the championship game was dismal.
8.origin: From Anglo-Norman French 'dis mal', from Latin 'dies mali' (evil days).

8.meaning_en: Conceal or disguise (one's thoughts, feelings, or character).
usage_sentences: He tried to dissimulate his anger by putting on a calm expression.
She was a skilled spy, able to dissimulate her true intentions.

8.meaning_en: Of or during the day; (of animals) active in the daytime.
usage_sentences: Humans are primarily diurnal creatures, active during the day and sleeping at night.
Most birds are diurnal, while owls are nocturnal.

8.meaning_en: Make known (private or sensitive information); reveal.
usage_sentences: The company refused to divulge the secret recipe for its famous sauce.
The journalist was pressured to divulge the name of her confidential source.

8.meaning_en: Relating to the upper side or back of an animal, plant, or organ.
usage_sentences: A shark's dorsal fin is its most recognizable feature.
The patient complained of pain in his dorsal region.

8.meaning_en: A person who sells cloth, curtains, and other fabrics.
usage_sentences: She went to the draper's shop to buy fabric for her new curtains.
In the 19th century, a draper was a common and important tradesman.

8.meaning_en: The nest of a squirrel, typically in the form of a mass of twigs in a tree.
usage_sentences: Looking up into the tall oak tree, we could see a squirrel's drey.
The drey provides shelter for the squirrel and its young.

8.meaning_en: Light rain falling in very fine drops.
usage_sentences: The game was postponed due to a persistent cold drizzle.
We decided to go for a walk despite the light drizzle.
8.origin: Possibly from an Old English word meaning 'to become covered with dew'.

8.meaning_en: An uncontrollable psychological urge to wander or travel.
usage_sentences: Suffering from dromomania, he would often disappear for weeks at a time.
Dromomania is a rare impulse-control disorder.

8.meaning_en: A herd or flock of animals being driven; a large number of people moving together.
usage_sentences: A drove of cattle was being herded down the dusty road.
Tourists came in droves to see the new attraction.
8.origin: From Old English 'drāf', related to 'drīfan' (to drive).

8.meaning_en: Hesitating or doubting; not to be relied upon; suspect.
usage_sentences: I was dubious about his claim that he could fix the car himself.
The politician has a dubious reputation for honesty.

8.meaning_en: A contest with deadly weapons arranged between two people to settle a point of honour.
usage_sentences: The two knights agreed to settle their dispute with a duel at dawn.
The famous politician Alexander Hamilton was killed in a duel.
8.origin: From Latin 'duellum', an archaic form of 'bellum' (war).

8.meaning_en: A long wall or embankment built to prevent flooding.
usage_sentences: Much of the Netherlands is protected from the sea by an extensive system of dykes.
Workers reinforced the dyke to prevent the river from overflowing.

8.meaning_en: A disorder involving difficulty in learning to read or interpret words, letters, and symbols.
usage_sentences: The child was diagnosed with dyslexia and given special help at school.
Many creative and intelligent people have dyslexia.

8.meaning_en: A self-supporting wooden frame for holding an artist's work while it is being painted.
usage_sentences: The artist placed a fresh canvas on the easel and began to paint.
The art classroom was filled with easels and paint supplies.

8.meaning_en: A person who secretly listens to private conversations.
usage_sentences: The spy was a skilled eavesdropper, able to gather information without being detected.
She lowered her voice, worried about potential eavesdroppers in the next room.
8.origin: From 'eavesdrop', referring to someone standing under the eaves of a house to listen.

8.meaning_en: (Of a person or behaviour) unconventional and slightly strange.
usage_sentences: The brilliant but eccentric professor was famous for his unusual teaching methods.
Her aunt was a lovable eccentric who collected garden gnomes.
8.origin: From Greek 'ekkentros', meaning 'out of the center'.

8.meaning_en: An overwhelming feeling of great happiness or joyful excitement.
usage_sentences: She was in a state of ecstasy after hearing the good news.
The fans were in ecstasy when their team scored the winning goal.
8.origin: From Greek 'ekstasis', meaning 'a standing outside oneself'.

8.meaning_en: Instruct or improve (someone) morally or intellectually.
8.meaning_hi: नैतिक या बौद्धिक रूप से सुधारना
usage_sentences: The purpose of his lecture was not just to inform, but to edify his listeners.
She read classic literature because she found it to be edifying.

8.meaning_en: Erase (a mark) from a surface; make oneself appear insignificant.
usage_sentences: The inscription on the old tombstone had been effaced by time.
He tried to efface himself in the crowd to avoid being noticed.

8.meaning_en: (Of a liquid) giving off bubbles; vivacious and enthusiastic.
usage_sentences: She dropped the tablet into the water and watched it become effervescent.
He was attracted to her effervescent personality and cheerful outlook on life.
8.origin: From Latin 'effervescere', from 'ex-' (out) + 'fervescere' (to begin to boil).

8.meaning_en: Believing in the principle that all people are equal and deserve equal rights.
usage_sentences: The movement fought for a more egalitarian society with equal opportunities for all.
She held strong egalitarian views and opposed any form of discrimination.

8.meaning_en: Outstandingly bad; shocking.
usage_sentences: The company was fined for its egregious violation of environmental laws.
It was an egregious error for a professional of his caliber to make.
8.origin: From Latin 'egregius', meaning 'illustrious', literally 'standing out from the flock'.

8.meaning_en: A supernatural creature of folk tales, typically small and with pointed ears.
usage_sentences: In many fantasy stories, elves are depicted as skilled archers and artisans.
Santa Claus is said to have elves who help make toys in his workshop.
8.origin: From Old English 'ælf', of Germanic origin.

8.meaning_en: The skill of clear and expressive speech, especially of distinct pronunciation.
usage_sentences: Politicians and actors often take elocution lessons to improve their public speaking.
His perfect elocution made him a pleasure to listen to.

8.meaning_en: Run away secretly in order to get married without parental consent.
usage_sentences: The young couple decided to elope because their parents disapproved of the marriage.
They eloped to a small town and were married by a justice of the peace.

8.meaning_en: A place or state of perfect happiness; paradise.
usage_sentences: After a long and difficult life, retirement felt like a well-deserved elysium.
In Greek mythology, Elysium was the final resting place of heroes.
8.origin: From Greek 'Ēlusion pedion', the Elysian plain.

8.meaning_en: Set free, especially from legal, social, or political restrictions.
usage_sentences: Abraham Lincoln issued the proclamation to emancipate the slaves.
The new laws were designed to emancipate women from their traditional roles.

8.meaning_en: An official ban on trade or other commercial activity with a particular country.
usage_sentences: The United Nations imposed a trade embargo on the rogue nation.
The embargo on oil exports caused a global energy crisis.
8.origin: From Spanish 'embargar', meaning 'to arrest, to impede'.

8.meaning_en: A small piece of burning or glowing coal or wood in a dying fire.
usage_sentences: He stared into the glowing embers of the campfire.
A single ember was enough to restart the fire.
8.origin: From Old English 'ǣmyrge', of Germanic origin.

8.meaning_en: Steal or misappropriate (money placed in one's trust).
usage_sentences: The accountant was caught trying to embezzle thousands of dollars from the company.
He embezzled funds from the charity and spent them on luxury goods.
8.origin: From Anglo-Norman French 'enbesiler' (to make away with).

8.meaning_en: Be an expression of or give a tangible form to (an idea, quality, or feeling).
usage_sentences: She was a leader who seemed to embody the values of courage and integrity.
The constitution embodies the fundamental principles of the nation.

8.meaning_en: (Of a former office holder, esp. a professor) having retired but allowed to retain their title as an honour.
usage_sentences: After 40 years of teaching, he was named Professor Emeritus of History.
As an emeritus professor, she still had access to the university library.

9.meaning_en: (Of a substance) causing vomiting.
usage_sentences: In case of poisoning, doctors may administer an emetic to induce vomiting.
Syrup of ipecac is a common emetic.

9.meaning_en: A person sent as a diplomatic representative on a special mission.
usage_sentences: The king sent an emissary to the neighboring kingdom to negotiate a peace treaty.
A special emissary from the United Nations arrived to help resolve the conflict.

9.meaning_en: Difficult to interpret or understand; mysterious; puzzling.
usage_sentences: The Mona Lisa is famous for her enigmatic smile.
He gave an enigmatic reply that left us with more questions than answers.

9.meaning_en: A feeling of listlessness and dissatisfaction arising from lack of occupation or excitement.
usage_sentences: A sense of ennui settled over him during the long, uneventful summer vacation.
The characters in the novel suffer from existential ennui and boredom.
9.origin: French, from a Latin word meaning 'it is hateful'.

9.meaning_en: A group of musicians, actors, or dancers who perform together; a coordinated outfit of clothes.
usage_sentences: The jazz ensemble played a fantastic set at the music festival.
She wore a stylish three-piece ensemble to the event.
9.origin: French, meaning 'together, at the same time'.

9.meaning_en: Lasting for a very short time; fleeting; transient.
usage_sentences: The beauty of the cherry blossoms is ephemeral, lasting only a week or two.
Fame in the world of pop music can be very ephemeral.

9.meaning_en: A person devoted to sensual pleasure, especially from fine food and drink.
usage_sentences: As a true epicurean, he traveled the world in search of the best culinary experiences.
The dinner was an epicurean delight, with multiple courses and fine wines.
9.origin: From Epicurus, a Greek philosopher who taught that pleasure was the highest good.

9.meaning_en: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of seizures.
usage_sentences: Modern medication can effectively control the seizures associated with epilepsy.
He was diagnosed with epilepsy as a child but leads a normal, active life.

9.meaning_en: A section or speech at the end of a book or play that concludes the work.
usage_sentences: The epilogue of the novel revealed what happened to the main characters ten years later.
In the play's epilogue, one of the actors steps forward to address the audience directly.

9.meaning_en: A letter (formal); a literary work in letter form.
usage_sentences: The New Testament contains several epistles written by the Apostle Paul.
He wrote a long epistle to the newspaper editor, outlining his views.
9.origin: From Greek 'epistolē', from 'epistellein' (to send a message).

9.meaning_en: Words written in memory of a person who has died, especially as an inscription on a tombstone.
usage_sentences: The simple epitaph on his tombstone read, 'A life well lived'.
She chose a poignant line from her favorite poem for her mother's epitaph.

9.meaning_en: An adjective or descriptive phrase expressing a quality characteristic of the person/thing.
usage_sentences: Richard the Lionheart' is a historical epithet for King Richard I.
In Homer's epic, the goddess Athena is often given the epithet 'grey-eyed'.

9.meaning_en: Mental calmness, composure, and evenness of temper, especially in a difficult situation.
usage_sentences: She faced the stressful situation with remarkable equanimity.
A good leader must be able to maintain their equanimity in a crisis.

9.meaning_en: An error in printing or writing. Plural: errata.
9.meaning_hi: मुद्रण या लेखन में त्रुटि; शुद्धिपत्र
usage_sentences: The publisher issued an erratum slip to correct a factual error in the book.
Please note the erratum on page 5, where a date was printed incorrectly.

9.meaning_en: A person, vehicle, or group accompanying another for protection or as a mark of rank.
usage_sentences: The president's limousine was accompanied by a police escort.
He offered to escort her home to make sure she arrived safely.

9.meaning_en: The study of the characteristics of different peoples and the differences and relationships between them.
usage_sentences: A professor of ethnology, she specialized in the cultures of Southeast Asia.
Ethnology helps us understand the diversity of human societies.

9.meaning_en: (Of a plant) make pale and weak through lack of light; make pale or sickly looking.
9.meaning_hi: पीला और कमजोर पड़ना; पीला पड़ना
usage_sentences: The plant that was left in the dark closet began to etiolate.
A lack of fresh air and sunshine can make a person look pale and etiolated.

9.meaning_en: The customary code of polite behaviour in society or among members of a particular group.
usage_sentences: Proper dining etiquette requires you to keep your elbows off the table.
It is considered a breach of etiquette to use your phone during a formal meeting.

9.meaning_en: The discredited study of/belief in improving human qualities by selective breeding.
usage_sentences: The Nazi regime's horrific policies were based on the pseudoscience of eugenics.
The history of the eugenics movement serves as a powerful ethical warning.

9.meaning_en: A speech or piece of writing that praises someone highly, typically someone who has just died.
usage_sentences: His son delivered a heartfelt eulogy at his father's funeral.
The biography was more of a eulogy than a critical assessment of his life.

9.meaning_en: A mild or indirect word or expression substituted for one considered too harsh or blunt.
usage_sentences: 'Letting someone go' is a common euphemism for firing them.
He used the euphemism 'collateral damage' to describe civilian casualties.

9.meaning_en: Relating to or having a pleasant sound; pleasing to the ear.
usage_sentences: The poet was known for the euphonic quality of his verse.
Her name was not only beautiful but also euphonic.

9.meaning_en: A feeling or state of intense excitement and happiness.
usage_sentences: There was a sense of euphoria in the city after the home team won the championship.
The runner experienced a feeling of euphoria as she crossed the finish line.

9.meaning_en: The painless killing of a patient suffering from an incurable and painful disease.
usage_sentences: The debate over the ethics and legality of euthanasia is complex and ongoing.
Some countries have legalized voluntary euthanasia for terminally ill patients.

9.meaning_en: Soon passing out of sight, memory, or existence; quickly fading or disappearing.
usage_sentences: The evanescent morning mist disappeared as the sun rose higher.
Youthful beauty is often evanescent, so it's important to value other qualities.

9.meaning_en: Expel (someone) from a property, especially with the support of the law.
usage_sentences: The landlord started legal proceedings to evict the tenants for not paying rent.
If they don't leave by the end of the month, they will be forcibly evicted.

9.meaning_en: A short extract from a film, broadcast, or piece of music or writing.
usage_sentences: The newspaper published an excerpt from the author's upcoming novel.
We listened to a short excerpt from the new symphony.

9.meaning_en: A short journey or trip, especially one engaged in as a leisure activity.
usage_sentences: The school organized a day excursion to the local science museum.
While on holiday, they took an excursion to see the nearby waterfalls.

9.meaning_en: Critical explanation or interpretation of a text, especially of scripture.
usage_sentences: The theologian wrote a detailed exegesis of the biblical passage.
Literary scholars often engage in the exegesis of classic texts.

9.meaning_en: An urgent need or demand.
usage_sentences: The exigencies of the war required the government to take immediate action.
Financial exigency forced the company to lay off some of its staff.

9.meaning_en: A mass departure of people.
usage_sentences: The economic crisis led to a mass exodus of skilled workers from the country.
The Bible describes the Exodus of the Israelites from Egypt.

9.meaning_en: Absolve (someone) from blame for a fault or wrongdoing.
usage_sentences: The new DNA evidence was enough to exonerate the man who had been in prison for 20 years.
The report exonerated the company from any wrongdoing.

9.meaning_en: (Of a price or amount charged) unreasonably high.
usage_sentences: The hotel charges exorbitant prices for its rooms during the peak season.
He complained that the mechanic's bill was exorbitant.

9.meaning_en: A person who lives outside their native country.
usage_sentences: Dubai has a large expatriate community from all over the world.
As an expatriate, he sometimes missed his home country.

9.meaning_en: Atone for (guilt or sin); make amends for.
usage_sentences: He tried to expiate his crime by dedicating his life to helping others.
The community held a ceremony to expiate the sins of the past.

9.meaning_en: Able to be accounted for or understood.
usage_sentences: His strange behavior was easily explicable once we learned about his past trauma.
The sudden drop in sales is not readily explicable.

9.meaning_en: Remove matter thought to be objectionable or unsuitable from (a book or account).
usage_sentences: The editor decided to expurgate the more explicit scenes from the novel for the school edition.
He read the expurgated version of the report, which omitted the sensitive details.

9.meaning_en: Spoken or done without preparation; impromptu.
usage_sentences: He was a gifted speaker, famous for his witty extempore speeches.
The comedian's performance was completely extempore and based on audience suggestions.
9.origin: From Latin 'ex tempore', meaning 'out of the time'.

9.meaning_en: Hand over (a person accused or convicted of a crime) to the jurisdiction of the foreign state where the crime was committed.
usage_sentences: The government agreed to extradite the fugitive to his home country to stand trial.
He fought against the request to extradite him.

9.meaning_en: An elaborate and spectacular entertainment or production.
usage_sentences: The opening ceremony of the Olympics was a musical and visual extravaganza.
The fashion show was a dazzling extravaganza of color and design.

9.meaning_en: A short story, typically with animals as characters, conveying a moral.
usage_sentences: The fable of 'The Tortoise and the Hare' teaches that slow and steady wins the race.
Aesop's Fables are a collection of stories with moral lessons.

9.meaning_en: Easily achieved; effortless; appearing neat by ignoring complexities.
usage_sentences: There is no facile solution to this complex problem.
He won a facile victory against an inexperienced opponent.

9.meaning_en: A mistaken belief, especially one based on unsound argument.
usage_sentences: It is a common fallacy that you can't get a sunburn on a cloudy day.
The argument is based on a logical fallacy and is therefore invalid.

9.meaning_en: (Of farmland) ploughed but left unsown for a period to restore fertility; inactive.
usage_sentences: The farmer left the field fallow for a year to improve the soil quality.
His creative skills had lain fallow for many years.
9.origin: From Old English 'fealg', of Germanic origin.

9.meaning_en: A person filled with excessive and single-minded zeal, especially for an extreme religious or political cause.
usage_sentences: He was a fitness fanatic, working out at the gym for three hours every day.
The religious fanatic was intolerant of anyone who did not share his beliefs.
9.origin: From Latin 'fanaticus', meaning 'of a temple, inspired by a god'.

9.meaning_en: The faculty of imagining impossible things; a genre of fiction involving magic.
usage_sentences: As a child, he lived in a fantasy world of dragons and wizards.
'The Lord of the Rings' is a classic work of fantasy literature.

9.meaning_en: The belief that all events are predetermined and therefore inevitable.
usage_sentences: His fatalism led him to accept his misfortunes without trying to change them.
Fatalism can sometimes lead to a sense of helplessness.
9.origin: From 'fatal', from Latin 'fatum' (that which has been spoken).

9.meaning_en: Possible to do easily or conveniently; likely; probable.
usage_sentences: It is not feasible to complete the project with the current budget.
We are looking for a feasible solution that works for everyone.

9.meaning_en: A deceptive or pretended blow, thrust, or movement.
usage_sentences: The boxer made a feint with his right hand and then landed a punch with his left.
Her apparent agreement was just a feint to get him to reveal his true plans.

9.meaning_en: Well chosen or suited to the circumstances; pleasing and fortunate.
usage_sentences: Her felicitous remarks put everyone at ease during the awkward silence.
It was a felicitous coincidence that they were both in the same city at the same time.

10.meaning_en: Relating to or involved in crime (specifically, a felony - a serious crime).
usage_sentences: He was charged with felonious assault after the brutal attack.
The gang was involved in several felonious activities, including robbery and extortion.
10.origin: From 'felon', from Old French, of Germanic origin.

10.meaning_en: A boat or ship for conveying passengers and goods on a regular service.
usage_sentences: We took the ferry to the island for a day trip.
A car ferry operates between the two coastal towns.
10.origin: From Old English 'ferian', meaning 'to carry, convey'.

10.meaning_en: A prolonged and bitter quarrel or dispute, typically between families or communities.
usage_sentences: The feud between the two families had lasted for generations.
A simple argument escalated into a major feud.
10.origin: From Old French 'faide', of Germanic origin.

10.meaning_en: Changing frequently, especially as regards loyalties, interests, or affection.
usage_sentences: The weather in the mountains can be notoriously fickle.
He criticized the fickle nature of public opinion.

10.meaning_en: Faithfulness to a person, cause, or belief; loyalty; the degree of exactness in reproduction.
usage_sentences: He swore an oath of fidelity to the king.
High-fidelity audio equipment reproduces sound with great accuracy.

10.meaning_en: A thing that someone believes to be real but that exists only in their imagination.
usage_sentences: The monster under his bed was just a figment of his overactive imagination.
She assured the child that the ghost was merely a figment.

10.meaning_en: The killing of one's son or daughter.
usage_sentences: The community was horrified by the tragic case of filicide.
The ancient myth tells a terrible story of madness and filicide.

10.meaning_en: An obsessive interest in or feeling about someone or something.
10.meaning_hi: स्थिरीकरण; किसी चीज़ पर अत्यधिक ध्यान
usage_sentences: He has a fixation on cleanliness and is constantly tidying up.
Her fixation on her past mistakes prevented her from moving forward.
10.origin: From Latin 'fixus', past participle of 'figere' (to fix).

10.meaning_en: A special or instinctive aptitude or ability for doing something well; stylishness.
usage_sentences: She has a natural flair for interior design.
He dressed with a certain flair that always made him stand out.
10.origin: From French, from 'flairer' (to smell), in the sense 'instinctive discernment'.

10.meaning_en: Tending to attract attention due to exuberance, confidence, and stylishness.
usage_sentences: The pop star was known for his flamboyant costumes and energetic performances.
He made a flamboyant gesture to emphasize his point.

10.meaning_en: A group of ships sailing together; a number of vehicles operating together.
usage_sentences: The fishing fleet set out from the harbor at dawn.
The company has a large fleet of delivery trucks.

10.meaning_en: A sudden quick movement or touch; to move or touch lightly and quickly.
usage_sentences: With a flick of his wrist, the magician made the coin disappear.
She flicked a speck of dust off her sleeve.
10.origin: Imitative of the sound or movement.

10.meaning_en: (Of light) shine or burn unsteadily; an unsteady light or movement.
usage_sentences: The candle flame began to flicker in the breeze.
We saw a flicker of movement in the shadows.

10.meaning_en: The reverse side of a record; an alternative or less familiar aspect.
usage_sentences: The flip side of his generosity was that he often expected something in return.
We enjoyed the party, but the flip side was the huge mess we had to clean up.
10.origin: From the practice of having a B-side song on the 'flip side' of a vinyl record.

10.meaning_en: Struggle or stagger clumsily in mud or water; be in serious difficulty.
usage_sentences: The horse began to flounder in the deep mud.
The new business was floundering and in danger of closing.

10.meaning_en: An unlikely chance occurrence, especially a surprising piece of luck.
usage_sentences: Their victory in the final was a complete fluke.
By a lucky fluke, I found a twenty-dollar bill on the street.
10.origin: Origin unknown, possibly from a term used in billiards.

10.meaning_en: A worker who supervises and directs other workers.
usage_sentences: The construction foreman gave instructions to the crew each morning.
As a foreman, he was responsible for the safety of his team.

10.meaning_en: The ability to predict what will be needed or happen in the future.
usage_sentences: She had the foresight to invest in the company when it was just starting out.
With a little foresight, we could have avoided this problem.

10.meaning_en: Lost or surrendered as a penalty for wrongdoing.
usage_sentences: The team forfeited the match because they did not have enough players.
If you cancel your booking, your deposit will be forfeited.

10.meaning_en: Make or shape (metal) by heating and hammering; produce a fraudulent copy.
usage_sentences: The blacksmith would forge horseshoes in his workshop.
He was arrested for trying to forge his employer's signature on a check.

10.meaning_en: (Of a person or speech) direct and outspoken; straightforward and honest.
usage_sentences: She was known for her forthright manner and always spoke her mind.
He gave a forthright answer, not trying to hide anything.

10.meaning_en: A period of two weeks.
usage_sentences: I will be on vacation for a fortnight in August.
The project is due in a fortnight.
10.origin: From Old English 'fēowertīene niht', meaning 'fourteen nights'.

10.meaning_en: Happening by accident or chance rather than design; happening by a lucky chance.
usage_sentences: A fortuitous meeting with a film director launched her acting career.
The discovery of the new drug was entirely fortuitous.

10.meaning_en: An infant that has been abandoned by its parents and discovered and cared for by others.
usage_sentences: The baby was a foundling, left on the steps of the church.
The story is about a foundling who grows up to be a hero.
10.origin: From the verb 'find', implying a child that has been found.

10.meaning_en: An entrance hall or other open area in a public building like a hotel or theatre.
usage_sentences: We agreed to meet in the foyer of the cinema before the movie.
The hotel had a grand foyer with a marble floor and a large chandelier.

10.meaning_en: Wild or distraught with fear, anxiety, or other emotion; hurried and disorganized.
usage_sentences: She was frantic with worry when her child went missing.
There was a frantic rush to finish the work before the deadline.

10.meaning_en: Filled with or likely to result in (something undesirable); causing anxiety.
usage_sentences: The situation was fraught with danger and uncertainty.
The atmosphere in the room was fraught with tension.

10.meaning_en: Fast and energetic in a rather wild and uncontrolled way.
usage_sentences: There was a scene of frenetic activity in the kitchen as the chefs prepared for the banquet.
The city has a frenetic pace of life that some people find exhausting.

10.meaning_en: A state or period of uncontrolled excitement or wild behaviour.
usage_sentences: The crowd was whipped into a frenzy by the rock star's performance.
In a frenzy of cleaning, she tidied the entire house.

10.meaning_en: Injury to body tissues caused by exposure to extreme cold.
usage_sentences: The mountaineer suffered severe frostbite on his fingers and toes.
It's important to wear warm gloves to protect against frostbite in cold weather.

10.meaning_en: Doing or handling something clumsily or uncertainly.
usage_sentences: He was fumbling in his pocket for his keys.
Her fumbling attempt to fix the machine only made it worse.
10.origin: From the verb 'fumble', probably of Scandinavian origin.

10.meaning_en: A tightrope walker.
usage_sentences: The crowd gasped as the funambulist walked across the high wire without a net.
Becoming a funambulist requires incredible balance and courage.

10.meaning_en: The main body of an aircraft.
usage_sentences: Passengers are seated in the main cabin, which is inside the fuselage.
The wings and tail are attached to the fuselage of the plane.

10.meaning_en: Annoying; humiliating; causing annoyance or resentment.
usage_sentences: It was galling to lose the game in the final minute.
He found it particularly galling that his rival was praised for his work.
10.origin: From the noun 'gall', referring to bile, a bitter substance.

10.meaning_en: (Of a message, sound, etc.) confused and distorted; unclear.
usage_sentences: The message over the radio was garbled and difficult to understand.
He gave a garbled account of what had happened.

10.meaning_en: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
usage_sentences: The garrulous taxi driver talked nonstop throughout the entire journey.
I was stuck sitting next to a garrulous old man on the plane.

10.meaning_en: The practice or art of choosing, cooking, and eating good food.
usage_sentences: France is world-renowned for its contributions to gastronomy.
He is a chef who is passionate about the science of gastronomy.

10.meaning_en: The branch of medicine or social science dealing with the health and care of old people.
usage_sentences: The hospital has a specialized ward for geriatrics.
As a doctor specializing in geriatrics, she treats many elderly patients.

10.meaning_en: A state, society, or group governed by old people.
usage_sentences: The political party was criticized for being a gerontocracy, with no young leaders.
In some traditional societies, a form of gerontocracy exists, where elders hold power.

10.meaning_en: A part of a city, especially a slum area, occupied by a minority group.
usage_sentences: During World War II, Jewish people were forced to live in crowded ghettos.
He grew up in a poor ghetto but worked hard to create a better life.
10.origin: From Italian, originally the name of an area in Venice where Jews were compelled to live.

10.meaning_en: Unintelligible or meaningless speech or writing; nonsense.
usage_sentences: He was so nervous that he started talking complete gibberish.
The baby was babbling happy gibberish.

10.meaning_en: Inflammation of the gums.
usage_sentences: Good oral hygiene, including regular flossing, can help prevent gingivitis.
The dentist told him he had a mild case of gingivitis.

10.meaning_en: A person whose trade is fitting glass into windows and doors.
usage_sentences: We had to call a glazier to replace the windowpane that was broken by the baseball.
The glazier carefully installed the large plate glass window in the storefront.

10.meaning_en: Have an angry or sullen look on one's face; scowl.
usage_sentences: He continued to glower at me even after I had apologized.
She didn't say anything, but just stood there with an angry glower.

10.meaning_en: Bite at or nibble something persistently; cause persistent distress or anxiety.
usage_sentences: The puppy likes to gnaw on old shoes.
The feeling of guilt began to gnaw at his conscience.
10.origin: From Old English 'gnagan', of Germanic origin.

10.meaning_en: Eat (something) hurriedly and noisily.
usage_sentences: The hungry children began to gobble down their pizza.
Don't gobble your food; you'll get indigestion.
10.origin: Imitative, also related to the sound a turkey makes.

10.meaning_en: A connoisseur of good food; involving high-quality or exotic food.
usage_sentences: He considered himself a gourmet and would only eat at the finest restaurants.
The hotel is famous for its gourmet cuisine.

10.meaning_en: Writing or drawings scribbled, scratched, or sprayed illicitly on a public surface.
usage_sentences: The subway cars were covered in colorful graffiti.
Some people consider graffiti to be art, while others see it as vandalism.

10.meaning_en: A storehouse for threshed grain.
usage_sentences: The farmer filled the granary with wheat after the harvest.
The old granary was converted into a rustic home.

10.meaning_en: Without charge; free.
usage_sentences: The museum offered admission gratis on the first Sunday of the month.
The lawyer provided his services gratis for the charity.

11.meaning_en: (Of a person) fond of company; sociable; (of animals) living in flocks or colonies.
11.meaning_hi: मिलनसार; सामाजिक; झुंड में रहने वाला
usage_sentences: She was a gregarious and outgoing person who loved being around people.
Dolphins are highly gregarious animals that live in large social groups.

11.meaning_en: (Of an animal) make a low guttural sound in the throat; (of a person) speak in a low, rough, angry voice.
usage_sentences: The dog started to growl at the stranger.
He would growl a response when he was in a bad mood.

11.meaning_en: (Of an animal, esp. a pig) make a low, short guttural sound; (of a person) make a low inarticulate sound.
usage_sentences: The pigs began to grunt happily when they saw the farmer bringing food.
He gave a grunt of effort as he lifted the heavy box.
11.origin: From Old English 'grunnettan', of imitative origin.

11.meaning_en: Easily persuaded to believe something; credulous.
11.meaning_hi: भोला-भाला; आसानी से धोखा खाने वाला
usage_sentences: He is so gullible that he will believe any story you tell him.
The scam artist targeted gullible people with promises of easy money.
11.origin: From 'gull', in the sense of 'to dupe'.

11.meaning_en: Swallow (drink or food) quickly or in large mouthfuls; swallow nervously.
usage_sentences: He was so thirsty that he began to gulp down the glass of water.
She let out a nervous gulp before stepping onto the stage.
11.origin: Probably from Dutch 'gulpen', imitative of the sound.

11.meaning_en: A sudden strong rush of wind; a sudden burst.
usage_sentences: A sudden gust of wind blew her hat off her head.
The rain was coming down in gusts.

11.meaning_en: A small settlement, generally smaller than a village.
usage_sentences: They live in a quiet hamlet with only a few houses and a church.
The artist moved to a remote hamlet to find peace and inspiration.
11.origin: From Old French 'hamelet', diminutive of 'hamel' (little village).

11.meaning_en: A basket with a lid for laundry or food; to hinder or impede movement or progress.
usage_sentences: Please put your dirty clothes in the laundry hamper.
The rescue efforts were hampered by the heavy snowfall.
11.origin: From Anglo-Norman French 'hanaper', a case for holding goblets.

11.meaning_en: A large building with an extensive floor area, typically for housing aircraft.
usage_sentences: The engineers worked on the airplane inside the spacious hangar.
The private jet was kept in a secure hangar at the airport.

11.meaning_en: A lengthy and aggressive speech; to lecture someone aggressively.
11.meaning_hi: उग्र और लंबा भाषण; उग्र भाषण देना
usage_sentences: The angry coach delivered a long harangue to the team after their poor performance.
She harangued her son about his messy room.
11.origin: From Old Italian 'aringa', from 'aringo' (public square, arena).

11.meaning_en: A person or thing that announces or signals the approach of another; a forerunner.
usage_sentences: The blooming of crocuses is a harbinger of spring.
In the story, the dark clouds were a harbinger of the coming storm.

11.meaning_en: A place on the coast where vessels may find shelter; to keep a secret thought or feeling in one's mind.
usage_sentences: The ships were safely moored in the harbour during the storm.
He started to harbour doubts about the sincerity of his friend.

11.meaning_en: A barbed spear-like missile used for catching whales and large sea creatures.
usage_sentences: In the novel 'Moby Dick', Captain Ahab is obsessed with hunting the white whale with a harpoon.
The whaler aimed the harpoon at the massive creature.

11.meaning_en: Acutely distressing; agonizing; painful.
usage_sentences: She gave a harrowing account of her escape from the war-torn country.
The survivors of the plane crash had a harrowing ordeal.
11.origin: From 'harrow', an agricultural implement used to break up soil.

11.meaning_en: Irritating inconvenience; to harass or pester.
usage_sentences: Getting a visa can be a real hassle with all the paperwork.
My younger brother loves to hassle me when I'm trying to study.
11.origin: Origin uncertain, possibly from a dialect word meaning 'to saw'.

11.meaning_en: A vehicle for conveying the coffin at a funeral.
usage_sentences: The long black hearse led the solemn funeral procession.
The coffin was carefully placed inside the hearse.
11.origin: From Old French 'herse', a kind of frame, originally one for holding candles over a coffin.

11.meaning_en: Interrupt (a performer or speaker) with derisive or aggressive comments.
usage_sentences: A group of protesters began to heckle the politician during his speech.
The comedian was so skilled that he could handle any heckler in the audience.
11.origin: From Middle English, related to 'hackle', a tool for combing flax.

11.meaning_en: A person who believes that the pursuit of pleasure is the most important thing in life.
usage_sentences: As a hedonist, his main goal in life was to maximize his own pleasure and enjoyment.
She accused him of being a selfish hedonist who cared for nothing but his own comfort.

11.meaning_en: Attracted to or thriving in sunlight.
usage_sentences: Sunflowers are heliophilous plants that turn to face the sun throughout the day.
Many desert plants are heliophilous and adapted to intense sunlight.

11.meaning_en: The therapeutic use of sunlight.
usage_sentences: In the past, heliotherapy was used to treat various skin conditions.
Spending some time in the sun for heliotherapy can boost vitamin D levels.

11.meaning_en: A faithful follower or political supporter, especially one prepared to engage in crime or violence.
usage_sentences: The villain in the movie had several loyal henchmen to carry out his evil plans.
The police arrested the gang leader and his top henchman.

11.meaning_en: A systematically arranged collection of dried plants.
usage_sentences: The botanist carefully mounted the dried plant specimen for the herbarium.
The university's herbarium contains samples from all over the world.

11.meaning_en: Belief or opinion contrary to orthodox religious doctrine; opinion profoundly at odds with what is generally accepted.
usage_sentences: In the Middle Ages, those accused of heresy were often persecuted.
His scientific theory was considered heresy by the established authorities of his time.

11.meaning_en: Enabling someone to discover or learn something for themselves; proceeding by trial and error.
usage_sentences: The teacher used a heuristic approach, guiding the students to find the answers on their own.
In computer science, a heuristic algorithm is a shortcut to find a good-enough solution.

11.meaning_en: Intellectual or scholarly in taste or nature (often disparaging).
usage_sentences: He only reads highbrow literature and looks down on popular novels.
The art exhibition was a bit too highbrow for my taste.
11.origin: From the late 19th-century belief that a high forehead indicated superior intelligence.

11.meaning_en: The remote areas of a country away from the coast or major rivers.
usage_sentences: The port city serves a vast agricultural hinterland.
They left the crowded city and moved to the peaceful hinterland.

11.meaning_en: Overly theatrical or melodramatic in character or style.
usage_sentences: She had a tendency for histrionic outbursts when she didn't get her way.
His speech was full of histrionic gestures and exaggerated emotion.

11.meaning_en: A stock or store of money or valued objects, typically one that is secret or carefully guarded.
usage_sentences: Archaeologists discovered a hoard of Roman gold coins buried in the field.
During the crisis, people began to hoard food and essential supplies.
11.origin: From Old English 'hord', of Germanic origin.

11.meaning_en: Destruction or slaughter on a mass scale; (the Holocaust) the mass murder of Jews under the Nazi regime.
usage_sentences: The world must never forget the atrocities of the Holocaust.
The threat of a nuclear holocaust was a major fear during the Cold War.

11.meaning_en: A structure of hexagonal wax cells made by bees to store honey and eggs.
usage_sentences: The beekeeper carefully extracted the honeycomb from the hive.
He enjoyed eating a piece of honeycomb with his breakfast.

11.meaning_en: A payment given for professional services that are rendered nominally without charge.
usage_sentences: The guest speaker received a small honorarium to cover his travel expenses.
The organization paid an honorarium to the consultant for his advice.

11.meaning_en: The cry of an owl; a shout or call expressing mockery or disapproval.
11.meaning_hi: उल्लू की बोली; उपहास की ध्वनि
usage_sentences: We heard the hoot of an owl in the woods.
The crowd began to hoot when the referee made a bad call.

11.meaning_en: A large group of people; a crowd; a migrating group.
usage_sentences: A horde of screaming fans greeted the rock star at the airport.
In the movie, a horde of zombies attacked the city.
11.origin: From a Turkic word 'ordu', meaning 'camp, army'.

11.meaning_en: Extremely unpleasant, horrifying, or terrible.
usage_sentences: The traffic jam on the highway was horrendous.
He described the horrendous conditions in the prisoner-of-war camp.

11.meaning_en: The art or practice of garden cultivation and management.
usage_sentences: She studied horticulture in college and now runs her own nursery.
The botanical garden is a beautiful example of skilled horticulture.

11.meaning_en: A person seized or held as security for the fulfilment of a condition.
usage_sentences: The bank robbers took several employees hostage.
Negotiators worked to secure the safe release of the hostages.

11.meaning_en: Having an impetuous or quick-tempered nature.
usage_sentences: He is too hot-headed to think rationally during an argument.
Her hot-headed reaction only made the situation worse.

11.meaning_en: Annoyed or irritated and quick to take offence at petty things.
usage_sentences: She got into a huffy mood when they teased her about her new haircut.
Don't get huffy; it was just a joke.

11.meaning_en: An assembly in which no single political party has an absolute majority of seats.
usage_sentences: The election resulted in a hung majority, forcing the parties to form a coalition government.
A hung majority can lead to political instability.
11.origin: From 'hung', in the sense of being suspended or undecided.

11.meaning_en: A box or cage, typically with a wire mesh front, for keeping small animals.
usage_sentences: He built a large hutch for his pet rabbits in the backyard.
The guinea pigs were kept in a clean hutch with fresh straw.

11.meaning_en: The science of surveying and charting bodies of water.
usage_sentences: The navy's hydrography department creates detailed charts for safe navigation.
Hydrography is essential for managing coastal resources.

11.meaning_en: A religious song or poem of praise to God or a god.
usage_sentences: The church service began with a well-known hymn.
The choir sang a beautiful hymn that moved the congregation.

11.meaning_en: Exaggerated statements or claims not meant to be taken literally.
usage_sentences: Saying 'I'm so hungry I could eat a horse' is a common example of hyperbole.
He was prone to hyperbole, often exaggerating his achievements.

11.meaning_en: A person who is abnormally anxious about their health.
usage_sentences: As a hypochondriac, he would visit the doctor for every minor ache and pain.
She convinced herself she had a rare disease, but it was just her being a hypochondriac.
11.origin: From Greek 'hupokhondria', referring to the upper abdomen, once thought to be the seat of melancholy.

11.meaning_en: A person who pretends to have moral standards they do not really possess.
usage_sentences: He's a hypocrite for criticizing others for gossiping when he does it all the time.
The politician was called a hypocrite for breaking his campaign promises.

11.meaning_en: A person who attacks or criticizes cherished beliefs or institutions.
11.meaning_hi: मूर्तिभंजक; रूढ़िवादी विचारों पर प्रहार करने वाला
usage_sentences: The artist was an iconoclast who challenged the traditional definition of art.
As a scientific iconoclast, he was not afraid to question established theories.

11.meaning_en: A mode of behaviour or way of thought peculiar to an individual.
usage_sentences: One of his idiosyncrasies was that he had to have everything on his desk perfectly aligned.
Her charming idiosyncrasy was her habit of talking to her plants.

11.meaning_en: The worship of idols; extreme admiration, love, or reverence for someone or something.
usage_sentences: Some religions consider the worship of statues to be a form of idolatry.
The fans' devotion to the pop star bordered on idolatry.

11.meaning_en: (Especially of a time or place) extremely happy, peaceful, or picturesque.
usage_sentences: They spent an idyllic week in a small cottage by the sea.
She remembered her idyllic childhood in the countryside with fondness.

11.meaning_en: An extremely confused, complicated, or embarrassing situation.
usage_sentences: The complex legal imbroglio involved multiple lawsuits and counter-claims.
The political scandal created a major imbroglio for the government.

12.meaning_en: Transfix or pierce with a sharp instrument.
usage_sentences: The butterfly was carefully impaled on a pin for the collection.
In the horror movie, the villain was impaled on a sharp fence post.

12.meaning_en: Unable to be felt by touch; not easily comprehended.
usage_sentences: The flour was ground into an impalpable powder.
There was an impalpable sense of sadness in the room.
12.origin: From late Latin 'impalpabilis', from 'in-' (not) + 'palpare' (to touch gently).

12.meaning_en: Treating all rivals or disputants equally; fair and just.
usage_sentences: A judge must remain impartial and base their decisions only on the evidence.
We need an impartial observer to mediate the dispute.

12.meaning_en: A policy of extending a country's power and influence through colonization or military force.
usage_sentences: The history of the 19th and early 20th centuries was shaped by European imperialism.
Many former colonies are still dealing with the legacy of imperialism.

12.meaning_en: Not showing proper respect; rude; insolent.
usage_sentences: The student was sent to the principal's office for his impertinent remarks.
It would be impertinent to ask someone how much money they earn.

12.meaning_en: Not allowing fluid to pass through; unable to be affected by.
usage_sentences: This jacket is made of a material that is impervious to rain.
He seemed impervious to the criticism and continued with his plan.

12.meaning_en: Lack of piety or reverence, especially for a god.
usage_sentences: Socrates was accused of impiety and corrupting the youth of Athens.
To the devout believers, his jokes about religion were a sign of impiety.

12.meaning_en: A person who pretends to be someone else in order to deceive others.
usage_sentences: The man claiming to be a long-lost heir was revealed to be an imposter.
She felt like an imposter among all the experienced professionals.
12.origin: From late Latin 'impostor', from 'imponere' (to impose upon).

12.meaning_en: (Of a fortified position) unable to be captured or broken into; unable to be overcome.
usage_sentences: The medieval castle was surrounded by an impregnable wall.
The team had an impregnable defense and did not concede a single goal.

12.meaning_en: Done without being planned, organized, or rehearsed.
usage_sentences: He gave a brilliant impromptu speech at his friend's wedding.
The friends decided to have an impromptu picnic in the park.
12.origin: From French, from Latin 'in promptu' (in readiness).

12.meaning_en: Not having or showing foresight; thoughtless; careless regarding the future.
usage_sentences: His improvident spending habits soon left him in debt.
It was improvident of them not to save any money for emergencies.

12.meaning_en: Not showing due respect for another person; impertinent.
usage_sentences: The impudent student answered the teacher back rudely.
It was impudent of him to ask such a personal question.

12.meaning_en: Exemption from punishment or freedom from the injurious consequences of an action.
usage_sentences: The dictator's son acted with impunity, knowing he was above the law.
You cannot break the rules with impunity in this organization.

12.meaning_en: Not alive, especially not in the manner of animals and humans.
usage_sentences: A rock is an inanimate object.
The artist had a special talent for making inanimate objects look lifelike in her paintings.

12.meaning_en: A person who embodies in the flesh a deity, spirit, or abstract quality.
usage_sentences: She was the incarnation of kindness, always helping those in need.
In Hindu belief, Vishnu has many different incarnations.

12.meaning_en: Designed to cause fires; tending to stir up conflict.
usage_sentences: The protesters threw incendiary devices at the police.
The politician's incendiary speech fueled the anger of the crowd.

12.meaning_en: Lack of patriotism.
usage_sentences: Refusing to participate in national celebrations was seen as an act of incivism.
The politician accused his opponents of incivism for questioning the country's motives.

12.meaning_en: Having one's true identity concealed.
12.meaning_hi: गुप्त वेश में; छद्म नाम से
usage_sentences: The famous movie star tried to travel incognito to avoid being recognized by fans.
The prince went incognito among his people to understand their lives.

12.meaning_en: Expressed in an incomprehensible or confusing way; unclear.
usage_sentences: After the accident, he was dizzy and his speech was incoherent.
The essay was poorly written and largely incoherent.

12.meaning_en: (Of a person or their tendencies) not able to be corrected, improved, or reformed.
usage_sentences: He is an incorrigible flirt who will never settle down.
Her incorrigible habit of being late always annoyed her friends.

12.meaning_en: (Of a person or their efforts) persisting tirelessly; untiring.
usage_sentences: She was an indefatigable campaigner for environmental protection.
He worked with indefatigable energy to complete the project.

12.meaning_en: Making marks that cannot be removed; not able to be forgotten.
usage_sentences: The traumatic experience left an indelible mark on his memory.
He signed the contract with an indelible ink pen.

12.meaning_en: Security or protection against a loss or other financial burden; compensation.
usage_sentences: The insurance policy provides indemnity against theft and fire.
The company had to pay a large indemnity for the environmental damage it caused.
12.origin: From Latin 'indemnis', meaning 'unhurt, free from loss'.

12.meaning_en: Originating or occurring naturally in a particular place; native.
usage_sentences: The Maori are the indigenous people of New Zealand.
That species of bird is indigenous to the region.

12.meaning_en: Feeling or showing anger or annoyance at what is perceived as unfair treatment.
usage_sentences: She was indignant at the false accusation.
He wrote an indignant letter to the editor to complain about the article.

12.meaning_en: Anger or annoyance provoked by what is perceived as unfair treatment.
usage_sentences: The news of the scandal was met with public indignation.
She was filled with indignation at the injustice of the situation.
12.origin: From Latin 'indignatio', from 'indignari' (to be angry at an unworthy action).

12.meaning_en: Absolutely necessary.
usage_sentences: A good dictionary is an indispensable tool for language learners.
He made himself indispensable to the team.

12.meaning_en: Too great or extreme to be expressed or described in words.
usage_sentences: The view from the top of the mountain was one of ineffable beauty.
She felt a sense of ineffable joy at the birth of her child.

12.meaning_en: Lack of skill or ability; incompetence.
usage_sentences: His ineptness at DIY projects was well-known; he couldn't even hang a picture straight.
The team's failure was due to the coach's tactical ineptness.

12.meaning_en: Certain to happen; unavoidable.
usage_sentences: After weeks of heavy rain, the flooding was inevitable.
It was inevitable that they would eventually get caught.

12.meaning_en: Impossible to stop or prevent; (of a person) impossible to persuade.
12.meaning_hi: निष्ठुर; जिसे रोका न जा सके
usage_sentences: The inexorable march of time waits for no one.
The committee was inexorable in its decision to reject the proposal.
12.origin: From Latin 'inexorabilis', from 'in-' (not) + 'exorabilis' (able to be entreated).

12.meaning_en: A place for the care of those who are ill or injured, often within a larger institution.
usage_sentences: The student felt unwell and was sent to the school infirmary.
The prison infirmary provides basic medical care to the inmates.

12.meaning_en: The complete flower head of a plant; the arrangement of flowers on a stem.
usage_sentences: The botanist studied the unique inflorescence of the rare orchid.
A sunflower is actually a composite inflorescence made up of many small flowers.
12.origin: From modern Latin 'inflorescentia', from 'inflorescere' (to begin to flower).

12.meaning_en: (Of a person) clever, original, and inventive; (of a machine or idea) cleverly designed.
12.meaning_hi: प्रतिभाशाली; चतुर; कुशलता से बनाया गया
usage_sentences: She came up with an ingenious solution to the difficult problem.
He was an ingenious inventor with many patents to his name.

12.meaning_en: A thing that is inherited (property, money, genetic characteristic, legacy).
usage_sentences: He used his inheritance to start his own business.
Eye color is a matter of genetic inheritance.
12.origin: From the verb 'inherit', from Old French 'enheriter'.

12.meaning_en: Not harmful or offensive; harmless.
usage_sentences: It was an innocuous-looking spider, but its bite was poisonous.
He made an innocuous comment that she completely misinterpreted.

12.meaning_en: An allusive or oblique remark or hint, typically a suggestive or disparaging one.
usage_sentences: The article was full of nasty innuendos about the politician's private life.
He spread rumors about his rival through suggestion and innuendo.

12.meaning_en: Treat with a vaccine to produce immunity against a disease; vaccinate.
usage_sentences: Doctors recommend that all children be inoculated against measles.
He was inoculated against typhoid before his trip to Asia.

12.meaning_en: Having or showing an interest in learning things; curious.
usage_sentences: Children are naturally inquisitive and ask a lot of questions.
She had an inquisitive mind and a thirst for knowledge.

12.meaning_en: (Of an appetite or desire) impossible to satisfy.
usage_sentences: He had an insatiable appetite for power.
She was an insatiable reader, often finishing a book in a single day.

12.meaning_en: Write or carve (words or symbols) on something, especially as a formal or permanent record.
usage_sentences: They decided to inscribe their initials on the old oak tree.
The watch was inscribed with a message of love.

12.meaning_en: Unable to pay debts owed.
usage_sentences: After years of losses, the company was finally declared insolvent.
An insolvent person cannot legally enter into new credit agreements.

12.meaning_en: Habitual sleeplessness; inability to sleep.
usage_sentences: Stress and anxiety are common causes of insomnia.
He suffered from insomnia for weeks, often lying awake all night.

12.meaning_en: Rebels or revolutionaries rising in revolt against established authority.
usage_sentences: The government struggled to control the territory held by the insurgents.
The army launched an offensive against the insurgents.

12.meaning_en: Unable to be touched or grasped; not having physical presence.
usage_sentences: A company's reputation and goodwill are valuable intangible assets.
There was an intangible quality of sadness about her.

12.meaning_en: Intervene on behalf of another; plead for someone.
usage_sentences: The union representative agreed to intercede with management on the employee's behalf.
She asked her influential uncle to intercede for her.

12.meaning_en: Obstruct (someone or something) so as to prevent them from continuing to a destination.
usage_sentences: The fighter jets were sent to intercept the unidentified aircraft.
The police managed to intercept the secret message.

12.meaning_en: A person who becomes involved where they are not wanted or do not belong.
usage_sentences: She felt like an interloper in their private conversation.
The locals were suspicious of the interloper who had moved into town.

12.meaning_en: An intervening period of time; an interval.
usage_sentences: There was a brief interlude of peace before the war started again.
The play had a short musical interlude between the two acts.

12.meaning_en: A person who acts as a link between people to bring about an agreement; a mediator.
usage_sentences: A neutral intermediary was brought in to facilitate the negotiations.
He acted as an intermediary between the two warring factions.

13.meaning_en: The burial of a corpse in a grave or tomb, typically with funeral rites.
usage_sentences: The family gathered for the interment of their beloved grandmother.
The interment ceremony was a somber and respectful occasion.
13.origin: From the verb 'inter', from Old French 'enterrer', based on Latin 'in-' (into) + 'terra' (earth).

13.meaning_en: Endless or apparently endless (often used hyperbolically); tediously long.
usage_sentences: The meeting seemed interminable, with no end in sight.
We had to sit through an interminable series of speeches.

13.meaning_en: The state of being confined as a prisoner, especially for political or military reasons.
usage_sentences: During the war, many citizens of enemy nationality were held in internment camps.
He wrote a book about his experience of internment.
13.origin: From the verb 'intern', from French 'interner', based on Latin 'internus' (inward).

13.meaning_en: Insert (something of a different nature) into something else; insert words into a text.
usage_sentences: The editor took the liberty to interpolate a few explanatory sentences into the author's text.
It is difficult to know which parts of the ancient manuscript were original and which were interpolated later.
13.origin: From Latin 'interpolare', meaning 'to refurbish, to alter'.

13.meaning_en: Place or insert between one thing and another; intervene between parties.
usage_sentences: She tried to interpose herself between the two fighting dogs.
He would often interpose a witty comment into the serious discussion.

13.meaning_en: A period when normal government is suspended, especially between successive reigns.
usage_sentences: There was a brief but chaotic interregnum between the death of the king and the coronation of his successor.
The company went through an interregnum while they searched for a new CEO.

13.meaning_en: Come between so as to prevent or alter a result or course of events.
usage_sentences: The teacher had to intervene to stop the argument between the two students.
The United Nations was asked to intervene in the conflict.

13.meaning_en: Not having made a will before one dies.
usage_sentences: Because he died intestate, his property was divided according to the law.
It's important to have a will to avoid dying intestate.
13.origin: From Latin 'intestatus', from 'in-' (not) + 'testatus' (having made a will).

13.meaning_en: Frighten or overawe (someone), especially in order to make them do what one wants.
usage_sentences: The bully tried to intimidate the smaller children into giving him their lunch money.
She was not a person who was easy to intimidate.

13.meaning_en: The examination or observation of one's own mental and emotional processes.
usage_sentences: A period of quiet introspection can help you understand your own feelings better.
His poetry is known for its depth and introspection.

13.meaning_en: Overwhelm (someone) with things or people to be dealt with; flood.
usage_sentences: After the commercial aired, the company was inundated with orders.
The heavy rains caused the river to inundate the entire town.

13.meaning_en: Not valid; legally void; a person made weak by illness or injury.
usage_sentences: The ticket was invalid because the date had expired.
After the accident, he was considered an invalid and needed constant care.

13.meaning_en: A complete list of items such as property, goods in stock, or the contents of a building.
usage_sentences: The store closes for one day each year to take a complete inventory of its stock.
Before moving, they made a detailed inventory of all their furniture.

13.meaning_en: Give strength or energy to; energize; refresh.
usage_sentences: The cold shower in the morning helped to invigorate him for the day ahead.
The new manager's fresh ideas helped to invigorate the tired team.

13.meaning_en: Too powerful to be defeated or overcome.
usage_sentences: After winning ten consecutive matches, the champion boxer seemed invincible.
The young team felt invincible after their surprise victory.

13.meaning_en: The action of invoking someone for assistance or as an authority; calling upon God in prayer.
usage_sentences: The ceremony began with an invocation to the gods for a bountiful harvest.
His speech included an invocation of the founding principles of the nation.

13.meaning_en: Having or showing a tendency to be easily angered; irritable.
usage_sentences: He was an irascible old man who would shout at anyone who disturbed him.
She had an irascible temper, especially when she was tired.
13.origin: From late Latin 'irascibilis', from 'irasci' (to grow angry).

13.meaning_en: Impossible to deny or disprove.
usage_sentences: The video footage provided irrefutable evidence of his guilt.
The scientific data is irrefutable and supports the theory.

13.meaning_en: Showing a lack of respect for people or things that are generally taken seriously.
usage_sentences: The comedian was known for his irreverent jokes about politics and religion.
His irreverent attitude often got him into trouble with his teachers.

13.meaning_en: Not able to be changed, reversed, or recovered; final.
usage_sentences: Once you sign the contract, the decision is irrevocable.
The damage to the ancient monument is irrevocable.

13.meaning_en: A narrow strip of land with sea on either side, forming a link between two larger areas of land.
usage_sentences: The Panama Canal was built across the Isthmus of Panama.
The isthmus is a strategically important piece of land.

13.meaning_en: A planned route or journey; a travel document recording these.
usage_sentences: Our travel agent prepared a detailed itinerary for our trip to Europe.
According to the itinerary, we will be visiting three cities next week.

13.meaning_en: A person employed as a caretaker of a building; a cleaner; a doorkeeper.
usage_sentences: The school janitor was responsible for cleaning the classrooms and hallways.
He worked as a janitor at the office building for over 20 years.

13.meaning_en: Special words or expressions used by a particular profession or group that are difficult for others to understand.
usage_sentences: The doctor's explanation was full of medical jargon that we couldn't understand.
To work in the tech industry, you need to be familiar with the latest jargon.
13.origin: From Old French, meaning 'chattering of birds'.

13.meaning_en: A short excursion or journey made for pleasure.
usage_sentences: We went for a little jaunt into the countryside for the afternoon.
They took a jaunt to the seaside on the weekend.

13.meaning_en: Cross or walk in the street unlawfully or without regard for approaching traffic.
usage_sentences: It is dangerous to jaywalk across a busy intersection.
The police officer gave him a warning for jaywalking.
13.origin: From 'jay', a name for a foolish person, + 'walk'.

13.meaning_en: Extreme patriotism, especially in the form of aggressive or warlike foreign policy.
usage_sentences: The politician's speech was full of jingoism and calls for military action.
Jingoism can lead to a dangerous sense of national superiority.
13.origin: From a British music-hall song of the 1870s.

13.meaning_en: A person or thing that brings bad luck.
usage_sentences: He thought he was a jinx because every team he supported seemed to lose.
Don't say that you're going to win; you'll jinx it!
13.origin: Possibly from a Latin name for the wryneck bird, associated with witchcraft.

13.meaning_en: A person who rides in horse races; to compete fiercely for position.
usage_sentences: The winning jockey celebrated after crossing the finish line.
The two companies were jockeying for control of the market.
13.origin: A diminutive of 'Jock', a Scottish form of the name 'John'.

13.meaning_en: Cheerful and friendly; hearty.
