usage_sentences: Santa Claus is often depicted as a jovial old man with a big laugh.
He was in a jovial mood, telling jokes and making everyone smile.
13.origin: From Latin 'Jovialis' (relating to the god Jove), as people born under the planet Jupiter were believed to be cheerful.

13.meaning_en: A military or political group that rules a country after taking power by force.
usage_sentences: After the coup, the country was ruled by a military junta.
The junta imposed a strict curfew and suspended all civil liberties.

13.meaning_en: Relating to young people; childish; immature.
usage_sentences: He was sent to a juvenile detention center for his crime.
His juvenile sense of humor was not appreciated in the serious meeting.

13.meaning_en: Place or deal with close together for contrasting effect.
usage_sentences: The artist would often juxtapose bright colors with dark shades in her paintings.
The article juxtaposes the poverty of the slums with the wealth of the city center.

13.meaning_en: A small shelter for a dog; a place where dogs are bred or boarded.
usage_sentences: We put our dog in a kennel while we were on vacation.
The dog curled up and went to sleep in its kennel.

13.meaning_en: The softer part within the hard shell of a nut; the central part of something.
usage_sentences: The kernel of a walnut is rich in healthy fats.
The kernel of his argument was that the current system was unfair.
13.origin: From Old English 'cyrnel', a diminutive of 'corn'.

13.meaning_en: A small open-fronted hut or cubicle from which newspapers, refreshments, etc., are sold.
usage_sentences: I bought a coffee and a newspaper from the kiosk at the train station.
You can buy tickets for the tour at the information kiosk.

13.meaning_en: A recurrent urge to steal, typically without regard for need or profit.
usage_sentences: She was diagnosed with kleptomania and received therapy for her condition.
Kleptomania is an impulse control disorder, not just simple theft.

13.meaning_en: An acquired or natural skill at doing something; a tendency.
usage_sentences: He has a knack for fixing things around the house.
She has a knack for always saying the right thing.

13.meaning_en: The sound of a bell, especially when rung solemnly for a death or funeral.
usage_sentences: The solemn knell of the church bell marked the beginning of the funeral.
The company's bankruptcy sounded the death knell for the small town's economy.
13.origin: From Old English 'cnyll', of Germanic origin.

13.meaning_en: A deep cut or tear in skin or flesh.
usage_sentences: He suffered a deep laceration on his arm from the broken glass.
The doctor had to put several stitches in the laceration.

13.meaning_en: A stretch of salt water separated from the sea by a low sandbank or coral reef.
usage_sentences: They spent the afternoon swimming in the warm, clear water of the lagoon.
The hotel had a beautiful view of the tropical lagoon.
13.origin: From Italian and Spanish 'laguna', from Latin 'lacuna' (pool).

13.meaning_en: A wild animal's resting place; a secret or private place.
usage_sentences: The bear returned to its lair to hibernate for the winter.
The villain's secret lair was hidden deep inside a volcano.

13.meaning_en: Relating to stone and gems and the work of engraving, cutting, or polishing them.
usage_sentences: He admired the lapidary work on the ancient gemstone.
A lapidary is a skilled artisan who works with precious stones.

13.meaning_en: A room or large cupboard for storing food.
usage_sentences: The old farmhouse had a cool, spacious larder for storing food.
She went to the larder to get a jar of jam.
13.origin: From Old French 'lardier', a place for storing bacon, from 'lard'.

13.meaning_en: (laurels) Honour or praise awarded for an achievement.
usage_sentences: After winning the championship, the team should not rest on its laurels.
She has won many laurels for her scientific research.
13.origin: From the laurel wreath, a symbol of honor in ancient Greece and Rome.

13.meaning_en: A medicine tending to stimulate or facilitate evacuation of the bowels.
13.meaning_hi: रेचक; पेट साफ़ करने की दवा
usage_sentences: The doctor recommended a mild laxative to relieve his constipation.
Overuse of laxatives can be harmful to your health.

13.meaning_en: Look or gaze in a lascivious, unpleasant, or malicious way.
usage_sentences: The creepy man in the corner began to leer at the young women.
She felt uncomfortable under his unpleasant leer.
13.origin: From an obsolete sense of the noun 'leer' meaning 'the cheek'.

13.meaning_en: Responsible by law; legally answerable; likely to do or be something.
usage_sentences: The company is liable for any damages caused by its products.
If you don't study for the test, you are liable to fail.

13.meaning_en: Eating mud.
usage_sentences: Certain species of earthworms are limivorous, extracting nutrients from the soil they ingest.
The biologist studied the digestive system of limivorous creatures.

13.meaning_en: Stay in a place longer than necessary, typically because of reluctance to leave.
usage_sentences: The delicious smell of baking bread lingered in the kitchen.
He tended to linger after the party, not wanting the evening to end.

14.meaning_en: A person skilled in foreign languages; a person who studies linguistics.
usage_sentences: As a linguist, she was fluent in over six different languages.
The linguist studied the grammatical structure of the ancient text.

14.meaning_en: Tending to talk a great deal; talkative.
usage_sentences: My loquacious aunt can talk on the phone for hours.
He was unusually loquacious after having a few drinks.

14.meaning_en: A quiet, gentle song sung to send a child to sleep.
usage_sentences: The mother softly sang a lullaby to her sleepy baby.
'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star' is a famous lullaby.

14.meaning_en: A person who inspires or influences others, especially one prominent in a particular sphere.
usage_sentences: The conference was attended by many luminaries from the world of science.
She is considered a luminary in the field of modern dance.

14.meaning_en: A person who is mentally ill (offensive term); extremely foolish or eccentric.
usage_sentences: You would have to be a lunatic to try to swim across the river in this storm.
The driver was a complete lunatic, speeding and weaving through traffic.

14.meaning_en: Make an abrupt, unsteady, uncontrolled movement or series of movements; stagger.
usage_sentences: The train gave a sudden lurch and then started to move.
He lurched to his feet and stumbled out of the room.

14.meaning_en: Being or involving the first attempt or act of its kind; (archaic) an unmarried girl.
usage_sentences: The ship's maiden voyage was from Southampton to New York.
The newly elected politician gave her maiden speech in parliament.
14.origin: From Old English 'mægden', a diminutive of 'mægð' (maid).

14.meaning_en: The first speech delivered by a person in a public forum like parliament.
usage_sentences: In her maiden-speech, the new member of parliament outlined her priorities.
His maiden-speech was well-received by his colleagues.

14.meaning_en: The mistaken use of a word in place of a similar-sounding one, often with amusing effect.
usage_sentences: He meant to say 'prodigy' but instead used the malapropism 'progeny'.
Her speech was full of unintentional malapropisms that made the audience laugh.
14.origin: Named after Mrs. Malaprop, a character in a play by Sheridan.

14.meaning_en: In a way that is clear or obvious to the eye or mind; clearly.
usage_sentences: The accusation was manifestly false.
It was manifestly clear that he was not telling the truth.
14.origin: From 'manifest', from Latin 'manifestus' (caught in the act).

14.meaning_en: A dummy used to display clothes in a shop window.
usage_sentences: The new spring collection was displayed on the mannequins in the shop window.
She thought the dress looked better on the mannequin than it did on her.

14.meaning_en: A movement or series of moves requiring skill and care; a cleverly planned scheme.
usage_sentences: The pilot performed a difficult manoeuvre to land the plane safely.
It was a clever political manoeuvre to win over the opposition.

14.meaning_en: An instrument for measuring the pressure of liquids and gases.
usage_sentences: The scientist used a manometer to measure the pressure of the gas in the container.
A simple U-tube manometer can be used to compare two pressures.

14.meaning_en: A large, impressive house.
usage_sentences: The movie star lived in a luxurious mansion in Beverly Hills.
The old Victorian mansion was said to be haunted.
14.origin: From Old French, from Latin 'mansio' (a staying).

14.meaning_en: A person who derives pleasure from their own pain or humiliation.
usage_sentences: You would have to be a masochist to enjoy running a marathon in the summer heat.
In psychology, a masochist is someone who finds gratification in suffering.
14.origin: Named after Leopold von Sacher-Masoch, a 19th-century Austrian writer.

14.meaning_en: A person skilled in cutting, dressing, and laying stone in building.
usage_sentences: A team of skilled masons built the beautiful stone wall.
The craft of a mason has been passed down through generations.
14.origin: From Old French 'masson', of Germanic origin.

14.meaning_en: A form of amateur dramatic entertainment, popular in the 16th-17th centuries.
usage_sentences: The royal court enjoyed a lavish masque with elaborate costumes and music.
Ben Jonson was a famous writer of court masques.

14.meaning_en: A performance in a theatre or a cinema that takes place in the daytime.
usage_sentences: We went to a Saturday matinee showing of the new film.
Matinee tickets are often cheaper than evening performances.

14.meaning_en: A service of morning prayer in various churches.
usage_sentences: The monks rose before dawn to attend matins.
The church bells rang to call the villagers to matins.

14.meaning_en: The state or ceremony of being married; marriage.
usage_sentences: The couple were joined in holy matrimony in a beautiful church ceremony.
The book is a guide to a long and happy life in matrimony.

14.meaning_en: A building, especially a large and stately one, housing a tomb or tombs.
usage_sentences: The Taj Mahal is one of the most famous mausoleums in the world.
The wealthy family built a grand mausoleum in the cemetery.
14.origin: From Greek 'Mausōleion', the magnificent tomb of Mausolus, a ruler in ancient Caria.

14.meaning_en: A short, pithy statement expressing a general truth or rule of conduct.
usage_sentences: He lived his life by the maxim 'honesty is the best policy'.
My grandmother had a maxim for every situation.

14.meaning_en: An area of grassland, especially one used for hay.
usage_sentences: The cows were grazing peacefully in the lush green meadow.
We had a picnic in a beautiful meadow full of wildflowers.
14.origin: From Old English 'mǣd', related to 'māwan' (to mow).

14.meaning_en: Of only average quality; not very good.
usage_sentences: The restaurant was disappointing; the food was mediocre and overpriced.
He gave a mediocre performance, which was unusual for such a talented actor.

14.meaning_en: A varied mixture of people or things; a musical piece incorporating tunes from different sources.
usage_sentences: The band played a medley of their greatest hits.
The salad was a medley of different greens, vegetables, and fruits.

14.meaning_en: Feeling or expressing pensive sadness; prone to melancholy.
usage_sentences: The melancholic music perfectly matched the sad mood of the film.
He had a melancholic nature and often seemed lost in sad thoughts.

14.meaning_en: A person or thing that is likely to cause harm; a threat or danger.
usage_sentences: The reckless driver was a menace to everyone on the road.
Pollution is a serious menace to the environment.

14.meaning_en: Given to begging; a beggar.
usage_sentences: In some religious orders, friars lead a mendicant life, relying on charity.
The mendicant sat by the side of the road, asking for alms.

14.meaning_en: Primarily concerned with making money at the expense of ethics; a professional soldier hired to serve in a foreign army.
usage_sentences: His motives for helping were purely mercenary; he expected to be well paid.
The warlord hired a group of foreign mercenaries to fight for him.

14.meaning_en: A change of the form or nature of a thing or person into a completely different one.
usage_sentences: The most famous example of metamorphosis is a caterpillar turning into a butterfly.
The city has undergone a complete metamorphosis in the last decade.

14.meaning_en: Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.
usage_sentences: She is a meticulous planner, and every detail of the event was perfectly organized.
The watchmaker's work requires meticulous attention to detail.

14.meaning_en: A period of a thousand years.
usage_sentences: The turn of the millennium was celebrated with huge events around the world.
These ancient trees have been standing for over a millennium.

14.meaning_en: A place where money is coined; a large amount of money; perfect condition.
14.meaning_hi: टकसाल; बहुत सारा पैसा; एकदम नई स्थिति
usage_sentences: The new coins were produced at the national mint.
That classic car must be worth a mint.

14.meaning_en: Dishonestly or unfairly take (something, especially money) for one's own use.
usage_sentences: The treasurer was found guilty of misappropriating the club's funds.
He misappropriated company resources for his personal projects.

14.meaning_en: An unlucky accident.
usage_sentences: The party went off without a single mishap.
There was a slight mishap in the kitchen, but the meal was not ruined.

14.meaning_en: A wrong or inaccurate name or designation.
usage_sentences: The name 'Greenland' is a famous misnomer, as the country is mostly covered in ice.
To call him a 'chef' is a misnomer; he can barely cook an egg.

14.meaning_en: A hater of new things or changes.
usage_sentences: As a confirmed misoneist, he refused to use a computer or a smartphone.
The company's progress was slowed by a few misoneists on the board.

14.meaning_en: A person who is skilled at mixing cocktails and other drinks.
usage_sentences: The trendy new bar hired a famous mixologist to create a unique drink menu.
A good mixologist understands the balance of flavors.
14.origin: A blend of 'mix' and 'ologist' (one who studies).

14.meaning_en: A particular way or method of doing something, especially one that is characteristic.
usage_sentences: The detective recognized the killer's modus operandi from previous cases.
Her modus operandi for studying is to create detailed flashcards.

14.meaning_en: Of great importance or significance, especially in its bearing on the future.
usage_sentences: The fall of the Berlin Wall was a momentous event in world history.
Choosing a career is a momentous decision for a young person.

14.meaning_en: A warning or caution regarding conduct; forewarning of danger.
usage_sentences: He ignored the monition from his financial advisor and made the risky investment.
The ancient text contained a monition against greed and arrogance.

14.meaning_en: A detailed written study of a single specialized subject or an aspect of it.
usage_sentences: The professor published a monograph on the life and work of a little-known poet.
His monograph on the subject is considered the definitive study.

14.meaning_en: Obsessive enthusiasm for or preoccupation with one thing.
14.meaning_hi: एक ही चीज़ का जुनून; एकोन्माद
usage_sentences: His interest in collecting stamps developed into a monomania.
Captain Ahab's monomania for the white whale led to his downfall.

14.meaning_en: The exclusive possession or control of the supply of or trade in a commodity or service.
usage_sentences: The company was accused of trying to create a monopoly in the software market.
In many countries, public utilities like water and electricity are a state-run monopoly.

14.meaning_en: A person who believes that there is only one God.
usage_sentences: A devout monotheist, she believes in the oneness of God.
Christianity, Judaism, and Islam are the major monotheistic religions.

14.meaning_en: Dull, tedious, and repetitious; lacking in variety and interest.
usage_sentences: Working on the assembly line was a monotonous job.
He spoke in a flat, monotonous voice that made it hard to pay attention.

14.meaning_en: Make fast (a boat); a tract of open uncultivated upland.
usage_sentences: The sailor moored the yacht securely to the dock.
They went for a long walk across the windswept moor.
14.origin: From Middle Dutch 'maren' (to fasten) and Old English 'mōr'.

14.meaning_en: The essential or characteristic customs and conventions of a community.
usage_sentences: The social mores of the Victorian era were very strict.
A traveler should be respectful of the local mores and customs.

14.meaning_en: A place where dead bodies are kept before burial or cremation.
usage_sentences: The detective went to the city morgue to identify the body.
A morgue is a necessary but somber part of any hospital.
14.origin: From French, the name of a building in Paris used for this purpose.

14.meaning_en: A legal agreement by which a bank lends money against property.
usage_sentences: They took out a 30-year mortgage to buy their first home.
Failing to make your mortgage payments can lead to foreclosure.

15.meaning_en: A room or building in which dead bodies are kept before burial or cremation.
usage_sentences: The body was transported from the hospital to the mortuary.
He worked as an attendant at the local mortuary.

15.meaning_en: A picture or pattern produced by arranging small coloured pieces of hard material.
usage_sentences: The ancient Roman villa had floors decorated with intricate mosaics.
The artist created a beautiful mosaic portrait using tiny pieces of colored glass.
15.origin: From medieval Latin 'mosaicum', from late Greek 'mouseion' (of the Muses).

15.meaning_en: A mound forming the site of a castle or camp.
usage_sentences: The ruins of the Norman castle stand on top of a large earthen motte.
A 'motte-and-bailey' was a common type of castle in the 11th century.
15.origin: From French, meaning 'mound, clod of earth'.

15.meaning_en: Wrap or cover for warmth; cover a source of sound to reduce its loudness.
usage_sentences: She muffled herself in a thick scarf to protect against the cold wind.
He tried to muffle his laughter with his hand.

15.meaning_en: Lacking interest or excitement; dull; of this earthly world.
usage_sentences: He wanted to escape his mundane life and go on an adventure.
Her job consisted of a series of mundane tasks like filing and data entry.

15.meaning_en: The action of mutilating or injuring severely (disfiguring or removing a part of the body).
usage_sentences: The ancient statue had suffered significant mutilation over the centuries.
The war resulted in the death and mutilation of thousands of soldiers.

15.meaning_en: An open rebellion against the proper authorities, especially by soldiers or sailors.
usage_sentences: The sailors on the ship staged a mutiny and overthrew the cruel captain.
The government acted quickly to suppress the mutiny in the army.

15.meaning_en: Nearsighted; lacking imagination, foresight, or intellectual insight.
usage_sentences: Being myopic, she needed glasses to see distant objects clearly.
The company's myopic focus on short-term profits led to long-term problems.

15.meaning_en: Fear of myths or stories or false statements.
15.meaning_hi: मिथकों या झूठी बातों का डर
usage_sentences: A person with mythophobia might be extremely skeptical of all folklore.
His mythophobia made him a very literal-minded person.

15.meaning_en: A person or thing that has the same name as another.
usage_sentences: He was named John after his grandfather, who is his namesake.
She was delighted to meet her namesake at the conference.
15.origin: From the phrase 'for the name's sake'.

15.meaning_en: Just coming into existence and beginning to display signs of future potential.
usage_sentences: The nascent tech industry of the 1980s has since grown into a global powerhouse.
She was a key figure in the nascent environmental movement.

15.meaning_en: Very bad or unpleasant; spiteful; malicious.
usage_sentences: There was a nasty smell coming from the garbage.
He made a nasty comment about her appearance.

15.meaning_en: Plan and direct the route or course of a ship, aircraft, or other form of transport.
usage_sentences: Ancient sailors used the stars to navigate across the open ocean.
She used a GPS to navigate through the unfamiliar city.

15.meaning_en: A sugary fluid secreted by plants; (in Greek myth) the drink of the gods.
usage_sentences: Bees fly from flower to flower, collecting nectar to make honey.
The sweet juice of the mango tasted like nectar.

15.meaning_en: A person who conducts negotiations.
usage_sentences: A skilled negotiator was brought in to help resolve the labor dispute.
As a negotiator, her job is to find a compromise that both sides can agree on.
15.origin: From 'negotiate', from Latin 'negotiari' (to carry on business).

15.meaning_en: The characteristic high-pitched cry of a horse.
usage_sentences: The horse let out a loud neigh when it saw its owner approaching.
We could hear the horses neighing in the stable.
15.origin: From Old English 'hnǣgan', of imitative origin.

15.meaning_en: The inescapable agent of someone's or something's downfall; a long-standing rival.
usage_sentences: The superhero finally faced his nemesis in an epic battle.
Procrastination was his academic nemesis.
15.origin: From Nemesis, the Greek goddess of retribution.

15.meaning_en: A newly coined word or expression.
usage_sentences: The word 'google' as a verb is a neologism that has entered common usage.
Writers like Shakespeare were known for creating many neologisms.

15.meaning_en: A person who is new to a subject, skill, or belief; a novice.
usage_sentences: As a neophyte in the world of coding, he had a lot to learn.
The experienced members of the team were patient with the neophytes.

15.meaning_en: Different from what one is used to; objectionably new.
usage_sentences: My grandfather refuses to use any of this newfangled technology.
He was skeptical of the newfangled teaching methods.
15.origin: From Middle English 'newefangel', fond of novelty.

15.meaning_en: A shallow recess in a wall; a comfortable or suitable position in life; a specialized segment of the market.
15.meaning_hi: आला; उपयुक्त स्थान; विशेष बाज़ार खंड
usage_sentences: She found her niche as a writer of historical fiction.
The small company carved out a niche for itself in the crowded market.
15.origin: From French, from 'nicher' (to make a nest).

15.meaning_en: The rejection of all religious and moral principles, often in the belief that life is meaningless.
usage_sentences: The character's philosophy was one of bleak nihilism.
Nihilism is the belief that nothing has any inherent value or meaning.

15.meaning_en: A transcendent state of enlightenment free from suffering; a state of perfect happiness.
usage_sentences: The ultimate goal of a Buddhist is to achieve nirvana.
For the stressed-out executive, a week on a quiet beach was pure nirvana.

15.meaning_en: Members of a people having no permanent abode, who travel from place to place.
usage_sentences: The Bedouin are nomads who have traditionally lived in the deserts of the Middle East.
The lives of nomads are shaped by the seasons and the search for resources.

15.meaning_en: A person whose behaviour or views do not conform to prevailing ideas or practices.
usage_sentences: She was a true non-conformist, always challenging authority and thinking for herself.
Artists and writers are often non-conformists.

15.meaning_en: A person or thing with no special or interesting qualities; an unimportant person.
usage_sentences: He went from being a nonentity to a world-famous celebrity overnight.
Working in a huge corporation, he often felt like a complete nonentity.

15.meaning_en: Having no match or equal; unrivalled.
usage_sentences: The chef's skill in the kitchen was nonpareil.
She was a singer of nonpareil talent.

15.meaning_en: An irrational belief that one is suffering from a specific disease.
usage_sentences: Despite clean bills of health from multiple doctors, his nosomania convinced him he had a rare illness.
Nosomania can be a symptom of a larger anxiety disorder.

15.meaning_en: The quality of being new, original, or unusual; a small inexpensive toy or ornament.
usage_sentences: The novelty of living in a new city soon wore off.
The tourist shop sold cheap souvenirs and other novelties.

15.meaning_en: A person new to or inexperienced in a field or situation.
usage_sentences: He is a complete novice at golf and has only played a few times.
The expert was happy to share her knowledge with the novices in the group.

15.meaning_en: A subtle difference in or shade of meaning, expression, or sound.
usage_sentences: A good actor can convey a wide range of emotions through subtle nuances of expression.
To truly understand the poem, you must appreciate the nuances of its language.

15.meaning_en: A person who studies the occult significance of numbers.
usage_sentences: The numerologist told her that her life path number indicated a creative personality.
She consulted a numerologist to help choose a lucky date for her wedding.

15.meaning_en: A person who collects or studies coins, medals, or paper money.
usage_sentences: The numismatist had an impressive collection of rare Roman coins.
As a numismatist, he could identify the origin and date of a coin just by looking at it.

15.meaning_en: A room for young children; a place where young plants are grown.
usage_sentences: They decorated the nursery in bright, cheerful colors before the baby arrived.
We bought all our plants for the new garden at the local nursery.

15.meaning_en: Extreme or irrational fear of the night or darkness.
usage_sentences: As a child, he suffered from nyctophobia and had to sleep with a night light on.
Her nyctophobia made camping trips impossible.

15.meaning_en: A stupid, uncultured, or clumsy person.
usage_sentences: The big, clumsy oaf knocked over a vase as he walked into the room.
Don't be such an oaf; use your manners.
15.origin: Probably from Old Norse 'álfr' (elf), with a sense change.

15.meaning_en: A fertile spot in a desert, where water is found.
usage_sentences: The weary travelers were relieved to find an oasis in the middle of the vast desert.
The small town was an oasis of green in an otherwise dry and barren landscape.

15.meaning_en: A notice of a death, especially in a newspaper, typically including a brief biography.
usage_sentences: The newspaper published a long obituary detailing her many accomplishments.
He was sad to read the obituary of his former teacher.

15.meaning_en: Not aware of or concerned about what is happening around one.
usage_sentences: Deep in his book, he was completely oblivious to the noise around him.
She was oblivious to the fact that everyone was staring at her.

15.meaning_en: A person who opposes the spread of knowledge or enlightenment.
usage_sentences: The obscurantist regime banned books and restricted access to information.
He accused the committee of being obscurantists for rejecting the new scientific theory.

15.meaning_en: Funeral rites or ceremonies.
usage_sentences: The king's obsequies were attended by royalty from all over the world.
The family held private obsequies for their deceased relative.

15.meaning_en: A building housing an astronomical telescope or other scientific equipment for observing phenomena.
usage_sentences: The powerful telescope at the mountain-top observatory allows astronomers to see distant galaxies.
The university has its own astronomical observatory for students and researchers.

15.meaning_en: Becoming obsolete; going out of use; becoming outdated.
usage_sentences: With the rise of smartphones, dedicated MP3 players are now largely obsolescent.
The factory was full of obsolescent machinery that needed to be replaced.
15.origin: From Latin 'obsolescere', meaning 'to fall into disuse'.

15.meaning_en: No longer produced or used; out of date.
usage_sentences: The floppy disk is now an obsolete form of data storage.
Many of the skills I learned in my first job are now obsolete.
15.origin: From Latin 'obsoletus', from 'obsolescere' (to fall into disuse).

15.meaning_en: Relating to the countries of the Occident (the West); Western.
usage_sentences: The museum had a collection of both Occidental and Oriental art.
He was a scholar of Occidental philosophy.
15.origin: From Latin 'occidentalis', from 'occidere' (to go down, set, as the sun).

15.meaning_en: A person who is from 80 to 89 years old.
usage_sentences: The sprightly octogenarian still went for a walk in the park every day.
My grandfather is an octogenarian who loves to tell stories about his life.

15.meaning_en: An ophthalmologist or optometrist (dated term).
usage_sentences: In the 19th century, you would visit an oculist for eye problems.
The old sign still read 'Dr. Smith, Oculist'.

15.meaning_en: A long and eventful or adventurous journey or experience.
usage_sentences: Their backpacking trip across South America was a real odyssey.
The book describes the author's personal odyssey of self-discovery.
15.origin: From the 'Odyssey', a long epic poem by Homer about the travels of Odysseus.

15.meaning_en: Obsession with or craze for wine.
usage_sentences: His oenomania led him to build a vast wine cellar with thousands of bottles.
A true connoisseur's passion for wine can sometimes border on oenomania.

15.meaning_en: A small group of people having control of a country or organization.
usage_sentences: Critics claim the country is run by a wealthy oligarchy of powerful families.
The ancient city-state of Sparta was an oligarchy.

16.meaning_en: Giving the worrying impression that something bad is going to happen; threatening.
usage_sentences: There were ominous dark clouds gathering on the horizon.
An ominous silence fell over the room.

16.meaning_en: A volume containing several books previously published separately; comprising several items.
usage_sentences: The publisher released an omnibus edition of the author's first three novels.
The government passed an omnibus bill that addressed several different issues.

16.meaning_en: The branch of zoology that deals with snakes.
usage_sentences: The researcher, an expert in ophiology, studied the venom of various snakes.
His fascination with reptiles led him to pursue a degree in ophiology.

16.meaning_en: Extreme or irrational fear of snakes.
usage_sentences: Her ophiophobia is so intense that she can't even look at a picture of a snake.
He developed ophiophobia after a frightening encounter with a snake in his childhood.

16.meaning_en: A medical doctor specializing in the diagnosis and treatment of eye diseases.
usage_sentences: The ophthalmologist performed surgery to remove her cataracts.
You should see an ophthalmologist for a comprehensive eye exam.

16.meaning_en: Characterized by conceited assertiveness and dogmatism.
16.meaning_hi: हठी; अपनी राय पर अड़ने वाला
usage_sentences: He is very opinionated and unwilling to listen to anyone else's point of view.
It's difficult to have a debate with someone so opinionated.

16.meaning_en: Harsh criticism or censure; public disgrace arising from shameful conduct.
usage_sentences: The disgraced politician faced public opprobrium after the scandal was revealed.
His cowardly actions earned him the opprobrium of his former colleagues.

16.meaning_en: A separate composition by a particular composer; any artistic work.
usage_sentences: The composer's final opus was a symphony dedicated to his wife.
His magnum opus is a novel that took him ten years to write.

16.meaning_en: A formal speech, especially one given on a ceremonial occasion.
usage_sentences: He delivered a powerful oration at the memorial service.
The valedictorian's oration was the highlight of the graduation ceremony.

16.meaning_en: A very unpleasant and prolonged experience.
usage_sentences: Being stranded in the desert for three days was a terrifying ordeal.
She bravely described her ordeal to the police.
16.origin: From Old English 'ordāl', a Germanic term for a trial by physical test.

16.meaning_en: An opening, as of a pipe or tube, or one in the body.
usage_sentences: Gas was escaping from a small orifice in the pipe.
The human body has several natural orifices.

16.meaning_en: An expert in the study of birds.
usage_sentences: The ornithologist identified the bird species by its distinctive song.
She is a dedicated ornithologist who has studied birds all over the world.

16.meaning_en: A residential institution for the care and education of orphans.
usage_sentences: After his parents died, he was sent to live in an orphanage.
The charity raises money to support orphanages in developing countries.

16.meaning_en: The branch of medicine dealing with the correction of deformities of bones or muscles.
usage_sentences: After his knee surgery, he was referred to the orthopaedics department for rehabilitation.
She is a surgeon who specializes in pediatric orthopaedics.

16.meaning_en: Turn into bone or bony tissue; cease developing; become rigid or fixed in attitude.
16.meaning_hi: हड्डी बन जाना; कठोर हो जाना
usage_sentences: As we age, cartilage can ossify and become less flexible.
His opinions had started to ossify, and he was no longer open to new ideas.

16.meaning_en: (Historically) a man employed to look after the horses of people staying at an inn.
usage_sentences: The traveller gave his horse to the ostler to be fed and groomed.
The job of an ostler was essential in the age of horse-drawn travel.

16.meaning_en: Exclude (someone) from a society or group.
usage_sentences: He was ostracised by his community for his controversial beliefs.
She felt ostracised by her colleagues after she reported the misconduct.
16.origin: From Greek 'ostrakizein', from 'ostrakon' (potsherd), as Athenians voted for banishment on pieces of pottery.

16.meaning_en: Be superior to in action or performance; surpass.
usage_sentences: Not to be outdone by his rival, he worked even harder to achieve his goals.
She always tries to outdo her older sister.

16.meaning_en: Looking or sounding bizarre or unfamiliar; foreign or alien.
usage_sentences: He showed up to the party wearing an outlandish purple suit.
She had some outlandish ideas that nobody else took seriously.

16.meaning_en: A person who has broken the law and remains at large; to ban or make illegal.
usage_sentences: Robin Hood is a legendary outlaw who stole from the rich to give to the poor.
The government passed a new law to outlaw the sale of certain chemicals.

16.meaning_en: The extent or length of reaching out; an organization's involvement in the community.
usage_sentences: The charity has an outreach program to provide food and shelter to the homeless.
The goal of the campaign is to increase public outreach and awareness.

16.meaning_en: Relating to or resembling sheep.
usage_sentences: The farmer specialized in ovine breeding and had a large flock of sheep.
The veterinarian was an expert on ovine diseases.

16.meaning_en: (Of an animal) producing young by means of eggs which hatch after laying.
usage_sentences: Birds, reptiles, and most fish are oviparous animals.
The platypus is a rare mammal that is oviparous.

16.meaning_en: A group of wild animals hunting together; a set of playing cards; to fill a space.
usage_sentences: We saw a pack of wolves in the national park.
He had to pack his suitcase quickly for the unexpected trip.
16.origin: From Middle Dutch, of Germanic origin.

16.meaning_en: A medical practitioner specializing in children and their diseases.
usage_sentences: The parents took their sick toddler to see a paediatrician.
A good paediatrician knows how to make children feel comfortable.

16.meaning_en: An elaborate public spectacle; a beauty contest.
usage_sentences: The town held a historical pageant to celebrate its bicentennial.
She competed in a beauty pageant when she was younger.
16.origin: From Latin 'pagina' (page), as scenes were once performed on movable stages or 'pages'.

16.meaning_en: (Of food or drink) pleasant to taste; (of an action or proposal) acceptable.
usage_sentences: The chef managed to make even the simple vegetables palatable.
They tried to find a solution that was palatable to both sides.
16.origin: From 'palate', the roof of the mouth, from Latin 'palatum'.

16.meaning_en: A word, phrase, or sequence that reads the same backwards as forwards.
usage_sentences: The word 'level' is a common palindrome.
He amused himself by creating long palindromic sentences.

16.meaning_en: The act of making a disease or its symptoms less severe without removing the cause.
usage_sentences: Palliative care focuses on the palliation of symptoms and improving quality of life.
The medication provided some palliation, but it was not a cure.
16.origin: From the verb 'palliate', from late Latin 'palliare' (to cloak).

16.meaning_en: Able to be touched or felt; (of a feeling) so intense as to seem almost tangible.
usage_sentences: The tension in the room was palpable as they waited for the verdict.
There is a palpable difference between the two products.
16.origin: From late Latin 'palpabilis', from 'palpare' (to touch gently).

16.meaning_en: Wild and noisy disorder or confusion; uproar.
usage_sentences: Pandemonium broke out when the famous actor appeared on stage.
There was pandemonium in the streets after the team won the championship.
16.origin: From 'pan-' (all) + Greek 'daimōn' (demon), coined by Milton in 'Paradise Lost'.

16.meaning_en: Gratify or indulge (an immoral or distasteful desire or habit).
usage_sentences: The newspaper was accused of pandering to the public's fascination with celebrity scandals.
A good leader does not pander to the prejudices of the crowd.
16.origin: From Pandarus, a character in Greek mythology and Shakespeare's 'Troilus and Cressida'.

16.meaning_en: A public speech or published text in praise of someone or something.
usage_sentences: The biography was a panegyric that ignored all of the subject's flaws.
He delivered a moving panegyric at his mentor's retirement party.

16.meaning_en: An unbroken view of the whole region surrounding an observer.
usage_sentences: From the top of the lighthouse, we had a stunning panorama of the coastline.
The book provides a broad panorama of 20th-century history.

16.meaning_en: Breathe with short, quick breaths; yearn.
usage_sentences: The dog was panting heavily after chasing the ball.
He was panting for a drink of cold water.
16.origin: From Old French 'pantaisier', possibly from Greek 'phantasioun' (to have visions).

16.meaning_en: A doctrine which identifies God with the universe, or regards the universe as a manifestation of God.
usage_sentences: Pantheism is the belief that God and the universe are one and the same.
Some poets express a form of pantheism in their reverence for nature.

16.meaning_en: A temple dedicated to all the gods; the gods of a people collectively.
usage_sentences: The Pantheon in Rome is a famous ancient temple.
Zeus was the king of the Greek pantheon of gods.

16.meaning_en: A theatrical entertainment; expressive communication by gestures alone.
usage_sentences: The children loved the Christmas pantomime.
He used pantomime to explain that he was thirsty.

16.meaning_en: A small room or cupboard in which food, crockery, and cutlery are kept.
usage_sentences: She found a can of soup in the back of the pantry.
The pantry was well-stocked with flour, sugar, and other baking supplies.

16.meaning_en: A simple story used to illustrate a moral or spiritual lesson.
usage_sentences: Jesus often taught using parables.
The parable of the boy who cried wolf teaches a lesson about honesty.

16.meaning_en: A lover, especially the illicit partner of a married person.
usage_sentences: The queen was rumored to have a secret paramour.
The historical novel was about the king and his paramour.
16.origin: From Old French 'par amour', meaning 'by love'.

16.meaning_en: A light umbrella used to give shade from the sun.
usage_sentences: In Victorian times, ladies often carried a parasol to protect their skin from the sun.
She sat under a large parasol on the beach.

16.meaning_en: Partly cook (food) by boiling.
usage_sentences: The recipe says to parboil the potatoes before you roast them.
Parboiling the vegetables helps to reduce the final cooking time.

16.meaning_en: Relating to a church parish; having a limited or narrow outlook.
usage_sentences: His views were too parochial for a global leader.
She grew up in a small, parochial town where everyone knew each other.

16.meaning_en: The killing of a parent or other near relative.
16.meaning_hi: पितृहत्या या निकट संबंधी की हत्या
usage_sentences: The trial for the gruesome crime of parricide shocked the nation.
In Roman law, parricide was considered one of the most heinous offenses.

16.meaning_en: A person of obscure origin who has gained wealth, influence, or celebrity.
usage_sentences: The old aristocratic families looked down on the parvenu as someone with new money but no class.
He was a parvenu who was desperate to be accepted by high society.
16.origin: French, past participle of 'parvenir' (to arrive, to succeed).

16.meaning_en: A very poor person.
usage_sentences: The novel tells the story of a prince who switches places with a pauper.
After losing his fortune, he died a pauper.

16.meaning_en: Embezzlement; theft of public funds.
usage_sentences: The government official was charged with peculation and corruption.
An investigation uncovered widespread peculation within the department.

16.meaning_en: The method and practice of teaching, especially as an academic subject.
usage_sentences: The university's education department offers courses in modern pedagogy.
His pedagogy emphasizes student participation and critical thinking.

16.meaning_en: A person who is excessively concerned with minor details and rules or with displaying academic learning.
usage_sentences: He is such a pedant that he corrects every small grammatical mistake people make.
Her boss was a pedant who cared more about rules than about results.

17.meaning_en: People walking along a road or in a developed area.
usage_sentences: The city installed new crosswalks to improve safety for pedestrians.
Drivers should always yield the right of way to pedestrians in a crosswalk.

17.meaning_en: The branch of medicine dealing with children and their diseases.
usage_sentences: She chose to specialize in pediatrics because she enjoys working with children.
The hospital has a renowned pediatrics department.

17.meaning_en: A strong or habitual liking for something or tendency to do something.
usage_sentences: He has a penchant for collecting antique maps.
She has always had a penchant for wearing bright, colorful clothes.

17.meaning_en: Engaged in, involving, or reflecting deep or serious thought.
usage_sentences: She was in a pensive mood, staring quietly out the window.
He had a pensive expression on his face as he considered the problem.

17.meaning_en: Lasting for a long time; enduring; (of a plant) living for several years.
usage_sentences: Lack of funding has been a perennial problem for the organization.
Perennial flowers will grow back year after year.

17.meaning_en: (Of an action) carried out with minimum effort or reflection.
usage_sentences: He gave a perfunctory nod as he walked past, barely looking up.
The inspection was very perfunctory and missed several key issues.

17.meaning_en: An arched structure in a garden consisting of a framework covered with climbing plants.
usage_sentences: They sat in the shade of a beautiful pergola covered in grapevines.
A wooden pergola was built over the patio to provide some shade.

17.meaning_en: Never ending or changing; occurring repeatedly.
usage_sentences: She was tired of his perpetual complaining.
The machine was designed to be in a state of perpetual motion.

17.meaning_en: A special right or privilege enjoyed due to one's position; a perk.
usage_sentences: A company car is a perquisite of the senior management position.
Access to the exclusive lounge was a perquisite for first-class passengers.
17.origin: From Latin 'perquirere', meaning 'to search for diligently'.

17.meaning_en: Subject (someone) to hostility and ill-treatment, especially because of their race, political, or religious beliefs.
usage_sentences: Throughout history, many groups have been persecuted for their religious beliefs.
The dictator would persecute anyone who dared to oppose him.

17.meaning_en: Harbouring infection and disease; morally corrupting; annoying.
usage_sentences: The stagnant swamp was a pestiferous breeding ground for mosquitoes.
He found the constant interruptions to be utterly pestiferous.

17.meaning_en: A heavy tool with a rounded end, used for crushing substances in a mortar.
usage_sentences: She used a mortar and pestle to grind the spices into a fine powder.
The ancient pharmacist prepared medicines with a pestle.

17.meaning_en: Decrease or fade gradually before coming to an end.
usage_sentences: The conversation started to peter out as it got later in the evening.
The team's energy seemed to peter out in the second half of the game.
17.origin: Origin uncertain, possibly from a reference to Saint Peter.

17.meaning_en: A long bench with a back, placed in rows in the main part of some churches.
usage_sentences: The family sat in their usual pew at the front of the church.
The old wooden pews were polished to a high shine.

17.meaning_en: A man who readily or frequently enters into casual sexual relationships with women.
usage_sentences: He had a reputation as a philanderer and was not trusted in relationships.
The main character in the story was a charming but incorrigible philanderer.
17.origin: From Greek 'philandros' (fond of men), but reinterpreted to mean 'fond of women'.

17.meaning_en: A person who collects or studies stamps.
usage_sentences: The philatelist was excited to add a rare 19th-century stamp to his collection.
He is a dedicated philatelist with albums full of stamps from around the world.
17.origin: From French 'philatéliste', from Greek 'philos' (loving) + 'ateleia' (exemption from tax, referring to the postage stamp).

17.meaning_en: A person who is hostile or indifferent to culture and the arts.
usage_sentences: He called me a philistine for not appreciating the abstract painting.
Only a philistine would fail to see the beauty in this classical music.
17.origin: From the Philistines, a people who were enemies of the Israelites in the Bible, later used metaphorically for an uncultured person.

17.meaning_en: The branch of knowledge dealing with the structure, historical development, and relationships of languages.
usage_sentences: J.R.R. Tolkien was a professor of philology at Oxford University.
Through philology, we can trace the ancient roots of modern words.

17.meaning_en: An enclosure for pigs; a very dirty or untidy place.
usage_sentences: The farmer cleaned out the pigsty once a week.
His bedroom was an absolute pigsty, with clothes and books all over the floor.

17.meaning_en: The action of stealing things of little value; petty theft.
usage_sentences: The store installed security cameras to reduce pilferage by customers.
The company was losing money due to constant pilferage from the stockroom.
17.origin: From the verb 'pilfer', from Old French 'pelfrer' (to pillage).

17.meaning_en: A seat for a passenger behind a motorcyclist.
usage_sentences: She held on tight as she rode pillion on the back of his motorcycle.
It is illegal for more than one person to ride pillion.
17.origin: From Scottish Gaelic 'pillean', a diminutive of 'peall' (a skin).

17.meaning_en: A person who is among the first to explore an area; one who develops new ideas.
usage_sentences: Marie Curie was a pioneer in the field of radioactivity.
The early pioneers traveled west in covered wagons to settle new lands.

17.meaning_en: Having a pleasantly sharp taste or appetizing flavour; pleasantly stimulating to the mind.
usage_sentences: The chef added a piquant sauce to the grilled fish.
She shared a piquant story about her travels that captivated the audience.

17.meaning_en: A person who attacks and robs ships at sea; one who reproduces copyrighted work illegally.
usage_sentences: In the old days, ships were often attacked by pirates in the Caribbean.
A software pirate sells illegal copies of popular programs.

17.meaning_en: (Of software, film, etc.) used or reproduced illegally.
17.meaning_hi: अवैध रूप से नकल किया हुआ
usage_sentences: He was caught selling pirated copies of the latest movies.
Using pirated software can expose your computer to viruses.

17.meaning_en: Make (someone) less angry or hostile; appease; pacify.
usage_sentences: The manager tried to placate the angry customer with an offer of a full refund.
She gave the crying child a toy to placate him.

17.meaning_en: (Of a person or animal) not easily upset or excited; calm.
usage_sentences: She has a very placid temperament and rarely gets angry.
The placid surface of the lake reflected the mountains perfectly.

17.meaning_en: The practice of taking someone else's work or ideas and passing them off as one's own.
usage_sentences: The university has a very strict policy against plagiarism.
He was accused of plagiarism for copying sections of his essay from a website.

17.meaning_en: A person who brings a case against another in a court of law.
usage_sentences: The plaintiff filed a lawsuit against the company for damages.
In a civil case, the person suing is called the plaintiff.

17.meaning_en: An ornamental tablet fixed to a wall commemorating a person or event; a sticky deposit on teeth.
usage_sentences: A blue plaque on the wall marked the house where the famous author was born.
Regular brushing and flossing helps to remove dental plaque.
17.origin: From French, from Dutch 'plakke' (a flat piece).

17.meaning_en: (Of an argument or statement) seeming reasonable or probable; believable.
usage_sentences: His excuse for being late sounded plausible, but I wasn't completely convinced.
The police are investigating a number of plausible theories.

17.meaning_en: The direct vote of all members of an electorate on an important public question.
usage_sentences: The government held a plebiscite to decide whether to join the international treaty.
The results of the plebiscite showed overwhelming support for the proposal.

17.meaning_en: Government by the wealthy; a state or society governed by the wealthy.
usage_sentences: Critics argue that the country is becoming a plutocracy, where money equals political power.
In a plutocracy, the needs of the poor are often ignored.

17.meaning_en: Evoking a keen sense of sadness or regret; touching.
usage_sentences: The photograph of the old man looking at his childhood home was deeply poignant.
It was a poignant reminder of how quickly time passes.
17.origin: From Old French, from 'poindre' (to prick, sting).

17.meaning_en: Relating to or involving strongly critical, controversial, or disputatious writing or speech.
usage_sentences: He wrote a polemical essay attacking the government's new policies.
The debate became polemical, with both sides refusing to compromise.

17.meaning_en: The practice or custom of having more than one husband at the same time.
usage_sentences: Polyandry is a rare form of marriage practiced in some Himalayan cultures.
The anthropologist studied the social structure of a community that practiced polyandry.

17.meaning_en: The practice or custom of having more than one wife or husband at the same time.
usage_sentences: Polygamy is illegal in many countries.
The documentary explored the lives of families in a culture that practices polygamy.

17.meaning_en: Knowing or using several languages.
usage_sentences: The tour guide was a polyglot who could switch effortlessly between English, French, and Spanish.
As a polyglot, she found it easy to find work in international relations.

17.meaning_en: Able to be easily carried or moved.
17.meaning_hi: वहनीय; आसानी से ले जाने योग्य
usage_sentences: He bought a small, portable speaker to take to the beach.
A laptop is a portable computer that you can use anywhere.

17.meaning_en: A range of investments; a set of pieces of creative work; the position and duties of a minister.
17.meaning_hi: निवेश सूची; कलाकृतियों का संग्रह; मंत्री पद
usage_sentences: The artist showed her portfolio to the gallery owner.
It is wise to have a diverse portfolio of investments.

17.meaning_en: A child born after the death of their father.
usage_sentences: The soldier's posthumous child was born two months after he died in battle.
The will made special provisions for any potential posthumous child.
17.origin: From 'posthumous', Latin 'postumus' (last, born after the father's death).

17.meaning_en: An additional remark at the end of a letter, after the signature (P.S.).
usage_sentences: She finished the letter but then added a postscript to say she had forgotten to mention something.
In his postscript, he wrote, 'P.S. I love you.'

17.meaning_en: A liquid mixture (often medicine, poison, or magic).
usage_sentences: In the fairytale, the witch brewed a magic potion that would make the princess fall asleep.
He drank the love potion and immediately fell for the first person he saw.

17.meaning_en: A mixture of dried petals and spices used to perfume a room; a varied mixture of things.
17.meaning_hi: सूखे फूलों का मिश्रण; विविध मिश्रण
usage_sentences: She kept a bowl of potpourri on the table to make the room smell nice.
The concert was a potpourri of different musical styles.

17.meaning_en: A person guided more by practical considerations than by ideals.
usage_sentences: While the idealist dreamed of a perfect world, the pragmatist focused on making small, practical improvements.
As a pragmatist, she chose the solution that was most likely to work, not the one that sounded best on paper.

17.meaning_en: An earlier event or action regarded as an example or guide in subsequent similar circumstances.
usage_sentences: The judge's ruling set a legal precedent for future cases of a similar nature.
There is no precedent for a situation like this.

17.meaning_en: A very steep rock face or cliff, typically a tall one.
usage_sentences: The car skidded and came to a stop just inches from the edge of the precipice.
The climbers carefully made their way up the steep precipice.

17.meaning_en: A person who held a job or office before the current holder.
usage_sentences: The new CEO implemented changes that were very different from his predecessor.
She inherited a difficult situation from her predecessor.

17.meaning_en: An introduction to a book, typically stating its subject, scope, or aims.
usage_sentences: In the preface, the author thanked everyone who had helped her with the book.
It's a good idea to read the preface to understand the author's intentions.

17.meaning_en: An action or event serving as an introduction to something more important.
usage_sentences: The small argument was a prelude to the major fight that followed.
The composer wrote a short prelude to begin the opera.

18.meaning_en: A strong feeling that something is about to happen, especially something unpleasant.
usage_sentences: She had a sudden premonition of danger and decided not to get on the plane.
He dismissed his feeling of unease as just a silly premonition.

18.meaning_en: Speak or act in an evasive way; avoid telling the truth by not directly answering a question.
usage_sentences: When asked about his involvement, the witness began to prevaricate and change his story.
Stop prevaricating and give me a straight answer.

18.meaning_en: Deep pleasure from achievements; consciousness of dignity; a group of lions.
usage_sentences: She took great pride in her children's accomplishments.
A pride of lions rested in the shade of the acacia tree.
18.origin: From Old English 'prȳde', of Germanic origin.

18.meaning_en: A person serving a probationary period in a job or position.
usage_sentences: As a probationer, her work was closely monitored for the first three months.
The new police recruits were probationers until they completed their training.

18.meaning_en: Spending money or resources freely and recklessly; wastefully extravagant.
usage_sentences: The prodigal son in the parable wasted his inheritance on a life of luxury.
He lived a prodigal lifestyle, spending money as if it would never run out.
18.origin: From late Latin 'prodigalis', from 'prodigere' (to drive away, waste).

18.meaning_en: A person, especially a young one, endowed with exceptional abilities or qualities.
usage_sentences: Mozart was a child prodigy who composed music from a very young age.
The young chess prodigy defeated several grandmasters.

18.meaning_en: Recklessly extravagant or wasteful in the use of resources; licentious.
usage_sentences: The profligate gambler lost his entire fortune at the casino.
The ancient Roman emperor was known for his profligate lifestyle.

18.meaning_en: Workers or working-class people, regarded collectively (often in Marxism).
usage_sentences: Karl Marx wrote about the inevitable conflict between the proletariat and the bourgeoisie.
The revolution was led by the proletariat, who sought to overthrow the ruling class.
18.origin: From French 'prolétariat', from Latin 'proletarius' (a person of the lowest class).

18.meaning_en: Rapid increase in numbers; rapid reproduction.
usage_sentences: The proliferation of nuclear weapons is a major global concern.
The internet has led to a proliferation of information, both good and bad.

18.meaning_en: A separate introductory section of a literary or musical work.
usage_sentences: The prologue of the novel sets the stage for the events that follow.
Shakespeare's 'Romeo and Juliet' opens with a famous prologue.

18.meaning_en: Continuing for a long time or longer than usual; lengthy.
usage_sentences: A prolonged drought caused severe damage to the crops.
He had to take a prolonged absence from work due to his illness.
18.origin: From the verb 'prolong', from late Latin 'prolongare'.

18.meaning_en: Having or involving many transient sexual relationships; indiscriminate.
18.meaning_hi: अनेक व्यक्तियों से यौन संबंध रखने वाला
usage_sentences: He had a promiscuous lifestyle in his youth but later settled down.
The report criticized the promiscuous use of antibiotics.

18.meaning_en: A pole or beam used as support; an object used by actors; to support.
usage_sentences: He used a wooden prop to keep the heavy branch from falling.
The actor forgot his prop and had to improvise.
18.origin: Probably from a Middle Dutch word 'proppe' (support for a vine).

18.meaning_en: A person who advocates a theory, proposal, or course of action.
usage_sentences: She is a leading proponent of renewable energy.
He was a vocal proponent of the new tax reform.

18.meaning_en: Forbid, especially by law; denounce or condemn.
usage_sentences: The new law will proscribe the use of certain dangerous chemicals.
The organization was proscribed for its involvement in illegal activities.

18.meaning_en: Institute legal proceedings against (a person or organization).
usage_sentences: The district attorney decided to prosecute the suspect for robbery.
Shoplifters will be prosecuted to the full extent of the law.

18.meaning_en: A person who has converted from one opinion, religion, or party to another.
usage_sentences: He was a new proselyte, eager to learn about his new faith.
The missionaries tried to win new proselytes.

18.meaning_en: The leading character or one of the major characters in a play, film, novel, etc.
usage_sentences: The protagonist of the story is a young hero on a quest.
We are supposed to sympathize with the protagonist, even when she makes mistakes.

18.meaning_en: A first or preliminary version of a device or vehicle from which other forms are developed.
usage_sentences: The engineers are currently testing a working prototype of the new electric car.
The first prototype had several flaws that were corrected in later versions.

18.meaning_en: Animal fodder; food.
usage_sentences: The farmer stored hay and oats in the barn as provender for his horses.
The travelers carried enough provender for their long journey.
18.origin: From Old French 'provende', from late Latin 'praebenda' (a grant).

18.meaning_en: A person who moves stealthily around a place with a view to committing a crime.
18.meaning_hi: चोरी के इरादे से घूमने वाला
usage_sentences: The police arrested a prowler who was looking into the windows of houses.
She was scared when she saw the shadow of a prowler in her backyard.

18.meaning_en: A person who studies elections and voting statistics.
usage_sentences: The psephologist analyzed the polling data to predict the election outcome.
Psephologists study voting patterns to understand political trends.

18.meaning_en: A fictitious name, especially one used by an author.
usage_sentences: George Orwell was the pseudonym of the writer Eric Blair.
She wrote her detective novels under a pseudonym.

18.meaning_en: The period during which adolescents reach sexual maturity and become capable of reproduction.
usage_sentences: The onset of puberty typically occurs earlier for girls than for boys.
Adolescence begins with the start of puberty.

18.meaning_en: Showing great attention to detail or correct behaviour.
usage_sentences: He was a punctilious host who made sure every detail of the party was perfect.
She was punctilious about following the rules of grammar.

18.meaning_en: A person who gambles; (UK informal) a customer or client.
usage_sentences: The successful punter won a large sum of money on the horse race.
The shopkeeper knew all his regular punters by name.
18.origin: From 'punt', a term in a card game, from French 'ponte'.

18.meaning_en: (Of organic matter) decay or rot and produce a fetid smell.
usage_sentences: The meat will putrefy if it is left out of the refrigerator for too long.
A terrible smell came from the pile of putrefying garbage.

18.meaning_en: An obsessive desire to set fire to things.
usage_sentences: The arsonist was diagnosed with pyromania by a psychiatrist.
Pyromania is a dangerous impulse control disorder.

18.meaning_en: The art of making or displaying fireworks; a brilliant performance.
usage_sentences: The New Year's Eve celebration included a spectacular pyrotechnics display.
The guitarist's solo was a display of technical pyrotechnics.

18.meaning_en: (Of a person's voice) shake or tremble in speaking.
usage_sentences: Her voice began to quaver with emotion as she told the sad story.
He was so nervous that his voice had a slight quaver.

18.meaning_en: A main wing or tail feather of a bird; a pen made from such a feather.
usage_sentences: In the past, people wrote with a quill dipped in ink.
The bald eagle dropped a large quill as it flew overhead.

18.meaning_en: Recurring every five years; lasting for five years.
usage_sentences: The association holds a quinquennial conference for its members.
The government launched a new quinquennial development plan.

18.meaning_en: Extremely idealistic; unrealistic and impractical.
usage_sentences: He had a quixotic plan to end world hunger all by himself.
While admirable, her quest to save every stray animal was quixotic.
18.origin: From Don Quixote, the hero of a novel by Cervantes.

18.meaning_en: A person who tells anecdotes in a skilful and amusing way.
usage_sentences: My grandfather was a wonderful raconteur who could captivate any audience with his stories.
A good raconteur knows how to pace a story for maximum effect.

18.meaning_en: Relating to fundamental nature; advocating thorough political/social reform.
usage_sentences: The new government proposed radical changes to the tax system.
He was a political radical who called for a complete overthrow of the existing order.

18.meaning_en: (Of writing/speech) lengthy and confused; walking for pleasure.
usage_sentences: His speech was a long, rambling account of his life story.
They spent the weekend rambling through the beautiful countryside.

18.meaning_en: Complex or unwelcome consequences of an action or event.
usage_sentences: The decision to close the factory had serious ramifications for the entire town.
We need to consider all the possible ramifications before we proceed.

18.meaning_en: Characterized by bitterness or resentment.
usage_sentences: The political debate was rancorous, with both sides trading insults.
Their divorce was a long and rancorous process.

18.meaning_en: Aggressively greedy or grasping.
usage_sentences: The rapacious corporation was accused of exploiting its workers.
He had a rapacious appetite for wealth and power.

18.meaning_en: A partial refund to someone who has paid too much; a deduction or discount.
usage_sentences: The company offered a cash rebate to customers who bought the new product.
After sending in the form, I received a rebate check in the mail.

18.meaning_en: Say that one no longer holds an opinion or belief.
18.meaning_hi: अपनी बात से मुकर जाना; त्याग देना
usage_sentences: Under pressure from the authorities, the scientist was forced to recant his controversial theory.
The witness later recanted her testimony, saying she had lied.

18.meaning_en: Summarize and state again the main points of.
usage_sentences: At the end of his lecture, the professor recapitulated the key arguments.
To recapitulate, our main goal is to increase sales by 20 percent.
18.origin: From late Latin 'recapitulare', literally 'to restate by heads or chapters'.

18.meaning_en: An object or space used to contain something.
usage_sentences: Please place all recyclable materials in the designated receptacle.
A flower is a receptacle for nectar.

18.meaning_en: Respond to (a gesture or action) by making a corresponding one.
usage_sentences: She was disappointed that he did not reciprocate her feelings of love.
They invited us to dinner, so we must reciprocate and have them over to our house soon.

18.meaning_en: A person who lives a solitary life and tends to avoid other people.
usage_sentences: The famous author became a recluse in his later years, refusing all interviews.
He lived as a recluse in a remote cabin in the woods.
18.origin: From Old French 'reclus', from Latin 'recludere' (to shut up).

18.meaning_en: Military observation of a region to locate an enemy or ascertain strategic features.
usage_sentences: A reconnaissance plane was sent to gather information about enemy positions.
The team conducted a thorough reconnaissance of the area before starting the mission.

18.meaning_en: Excessive bureaucracy or adherence to official rules and formalities.
usage_sentences: The project was delayed for months due to government red-tapism.
Entrepreneurs often complain about the red-tapism involved in starting a new business.
18.origin: From the red or pink tape formerly used to tie up official documents.

18.meaning_en: Not or no longer needed or useful; (of worker) no longer employed due to job non-existence.
usage_sentences: With the new software, many of our old manual processes have become redundant.
He was made redundant when the company downsized.

18.meaning_en: A general vote by the electorate on a single political question.
usage_sentences: The country held a referendum to decide whether to change its constitution.
The result of the referendum was very close.
18.origin: Latin, meaning 'thing to be brought back or referred'.

18.meaning_en: The emblems or insignia of royalty; distinctive clothing worn at formal ceremonies.
usage_sentences: The king appeared at the ceremony in his full royal regalia, including his crown and sceptre.
The university professors wore their academic regalia for the graduation.

19.meaning_en: An object surviving from an earlier time, especially one of historical or sentimental interest.
usage_sentences: The museum displayed ancient relics from the Roman Empire.
This old photograph is a precious family relic.

19.meaning_en: Place (a defendant) on bail or in custody, especially when a trial is adjourned.
usage_sentences: The judge decided to remand the suspect in custody until the next hearing.
He was on remand for six weeks before his trial began.

19.meaning_en: Accounts of past experiences remembered; the enjoyable recollection of past events.
usage_sentences: His book is a collection of charming reminiscences about his childhood.
The old friends spent the evening sharing reminiscences of their school days.

19.meaning_en: Money paid for work or a service.
usage_sentences: The job offers a competitive salary and an excellent remuneration package.
The remuneration for this position will be based on experience.

19.meaning_en: A performance or interpretation, especially of a dramatic role or piece of music.
usage_sentences: Her rendition of the classic song was both powerful and emotional.
The actor's rendition of Hamlet received critical acclaim.
19.origin: From medieval Latin 'rendere' (to give back, render).

19.meaning_en: A person who deserts and betrays an organization, country, or set of principles.
usage_sentences: He was declared a renegade for abandoning his post and joining the enemy.
The renegade agent sold government secrets to a foreign power.
19.origin: From Spanish 'renegado', from medieval Latin 'renegare' (to renounce).

19.meaning_en: Conversation characterized by quick, witty comments or replies.
usage_sentences: The two comedians were masters of witty repartee.
Their clever repartee kept the audience laughing.

19.meaning_en: The return of someone to their own country; the sending back of money.
usage_sentences: The government organized the repatriation of its citizens from the war-torn region.
The repatriation of profits is a key concern for multinational corporations.
19.origin: From 'repatriate', from late Latin 'repatriare' (to return to one's country).

19.meaning_en: An unintended consequence occurring some time after an event, especially an unwelcome one.
usage_sentences: The decision to raise interest rates had serious repercussions for the housing market.
He did not consider the possible repercussions of his actions.

19.meaning_en: Cancel or postpone the punishment of (someone); give relief from something unpleasant.
usage_sentences: The governor granted the condemned prisoner a last-minute reprieve.
The rainy weather provided a welcome reprieve from the summer heat.

19.meaning_en: Able to withstand or recover quickly from difficult conditions.
19.meaning_hi: लचीला; कठिनाइयों से उबरने में सक्षम
usage_sentences: Children are often more resilient than adults in dealing with change.
The local economy has proven to be surprisingly resilient to the recession.

19.meaning_en: A short period of rest or relief from something difficult or unpleasant.
usage_sentences: The caregivers were grateful for the brief respite from their demanding duties.
There was no respite from the constant noise of the city.
19.origin: From Old French 'respit', from Latin 'respectus' (respect, consideration).

19.meaning_en: The restoration of something lost or stolen to its proper owner; recompense for injury or loss.
usage_sentences: The court ordered the thief to make full restitution to his victims.
The museum is working on the restitution of artworks stolen during the war.

19.meaning_en: Not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily; reserved.
usage_sentences: He was very reticent about his personal life and rarely spoke about his past.
She is a shy and reticent person who does not enjoy public speaking.

19.meaning_en: The action of looking back on or reviewing past events or situations.
usage_sentences: In retrospection, he realized that he should have made a different decision.
Her memoir was a journey of retrospection, exploring the key moments of her life.

19.meaning_en: Give new and improved form, structure, or appearance to.
usage_sentences: The company decided to revamp its outdated website.
They are planning to revamp the entire kitchen.

19.meaning_en: A signal sounded on a bugle or drum to wake personnel in armed forces.
usage_sentences: The soldiers were woken at 6 a.m. by the sound of reveille.
His day in the army began with reveille and ended with taps.

19.meaning_en: Enjoy oneself in a lively and noisy way; take great pleasure in.
usage_sentences: The fans continued to revel in their team's victory long after the game was over.
She reveled in the opportunity to showcase her talent.

19.meaning_en: Feeling or showing deep and solemn respect.
usage_sentences: They spoke in hushed, reverent tones inside the ancient temple.
He has a reverent attitude towards nature.

19.meaning_en: A state of being pleasantly lost in one's thoughts; a daydream.
usage_sentences: She was lost in a reverie and didn't hear the teacher call her name.
He was startled out of his reverie by the sound of the phone ringing.

19.meaning_en: Criticize in an abusive or angrily insulting manner.
usage_sentences: The politician was reviled by the public for his corrupt practices.
He was reviled as a traitor by his former colleagues.

19.meaning_en: The art of effective or persuasive speaking or writing; language designed to impress but lacking sincerity.
usage_sentences: The speech was full of powerful rhetoric that moved the audience.
The people were tired of the politician's empty rhetoric and wanted action.
19.origin: From Greek 'rhētorikē (tekhnē)', meaning '(art) of an orator'.

19.meaning_en: A medical specialist who deals with the nose and its diseases.
usage_sentences: He consulted a rhinologist for his chronic sinus problems.
The rhinologist performed surgery to correct a deviated septum.

19.meaning_en: A round building or room, especially one with a dome.
usage_sentences: The U.S. Capitol building is famous for its large central rotunda.
The main reading room of the library was a magnificent rotunda.

19.meaning_en: The physical remains of something that has been destroyed or decayed.
usage_sentences: They spent the day exploring the ancient ruins of a Roman city.
The castle was left in ruins after the war.

19.meaning_en: Deliberately destroy, damage, or obstruct (something), especially for political or military advantage.
usage_sentences: The striking workers were accused of trying to sabotage the factory's machinery.
He suspected his rival of trying to sabotage his project.
19.origin: From French 'saboter', from 'sabot' (a type of wooden shoe), referring to workers throwing shoes into machinery.

19.meaning_en: A person who tends to be disorganized and forgetful.
usage_sentences: She is such a scatterbrain that she's always losing her keys.
As a scatterbrain, I have to write everything down or I'll forget it.

19.meaning_en: Violation or misuse of what is regarded as sacred.
usage_sentences: It is considered sacrilege to vandalize a place of worship.
To the devout fan, criticizing the legendary player was a form of sacrilege.

19.meaning_en: Deriving pleasure from inflicting pain, suffering, or humiliation on others.
usage_sentences: The cruel villain took sadistic pleasure in his evil deeds.
He has a sadistic sense of humor and enjoys seeing others embarrassed.
19.origin: From the name of the Marquis de Sade, an 18th-century French writer.

19.meaning_en: A simultaneous discharge of artillery or firearms; a sudden burst.
19.meaning_hi: तोपों की सलामी; प्रश्नों की बौछार
usage_sentences: The battleship fired a salvo of its main guns.
The politician was met with a salvo of questions from the reporters.

19.meaning_en: A charitable or helpful person (from the parable of the Good Samaritan).
usage_sentences: A Good Samaritan stopped to help me change my flat tire.
She is a true Samaritan, always willing to help those in need.
19.origin: From the biblical parable of the Good Samaritan in the New Testament.

19.meaning_en: (Historically in the Soviet Union) the clandestine copying and distribution of banned literature.
usage_sentences: Dissident writers circulated their work through the samizdat system.
The book was first published as a samizdat in the author's home country.

19.meaning_en: An establishment for the medical treatment of people with chronic illnesses.
usage_sentences: In the past, patients with tuberculosis were sent to a sanatorium in the mountains.
The old sanatorium has now been converted into a luxury hotel.

19.meaning_en: The state or quality of being holy, sacred, or saintly.
usage_sentences: Many religions believe in the sanctity of human life.
The lawyer argued for the sanctity of the contract.

19.meaning_en: Involving or causing much bloodshed.
usage_sentences: The history of the revolution was a long and sanguinary one.
The battle was one of the most sanguinary in the country's history.

19.meaning_en: Optimistic or positive, especially in an apparently bad or difficult situation.
usage_sentences: Despite the bad news, he remained sanguine about the company's future.
She has a sanguine temperament and always looks on the bright side.
19.origin: From Latin 'sanguis' (blood), relating to the four humors of ancient medicine.

19.meaning_en: Tasting (good food or drink) and enjoying it to the full; enjoying an experience slowly.
usage_sentences: He closed his eyes, savouring the delicious taste of the chocolate.
She was savouring every moment of her last day of vacation.

19.meaning_en: A sheath for the blade of a sword or dagger.
usage_sentences: The knight drew his sword from its ornate scabbard.
He returned the dagger to its scabbard at his belt.
19.origin: From Anglo-Norman French 'escauberc', of Germanic origin.

19.meaning_en: Barely sufficient or adequate.
usage_sentences: He paid scant attention to the details of the report.
Food was scant during the long winter.

19.meaning_en: Search for and collect (anything usable) from discarded waste; (of animal) feed on carrion.
usage_sentences: Vultures are known to scavenge for food.
He would scavenge for spare parts in the junkyard.

19.meaning_en: An ornamented staff carried by rulers on ceremonial occasions as a symbol of sovereignty.
usage_sentences: The queen held the royal sceptre during her coronation.
The orb and sceptre are important symbols of the monarchy.

19.meaning_en: A person inclined to question or doubt accepted opinions.
usage_sentences: He was a skeptic who demanded proof before he would believe anything.
Even after seeing the evidence, she remained a skeptic.

19.meaning_en: An institution for educating children; a large group of fish or aquatic mammals.
usage_sentences: My daughter is excited to start school next year.
We saw a large school of dolphins swimming alongside the boat.
19.origin: From Greek 'skholē' (leisure, lecture) and Middle Dutch 'schole' (troop).

19.meaning_en: Sparkling or shining brightly; brilliantly and excitingly clever or skillful.
usage_sentences: She was a scintillating conversationalist who could talk about any subject.
The diamond gave off a scintillating light.

19.meaning_en: The number of points in a game; a group or set of twenty.
usage_sentences: The final score of the game was three to one.
The biblical phrase 'three score years and ten' means seventy years.

19.meaning_en: Give a loud, harsh, piercing cry.
usage_sentences: The car's tires let out a loud screech as it stopped suddenly.
She let out a screech of terror when she saw the spider.

19.meaning_en: Loud, harsh, and piercing (sound).
usage_sentences: The old door hinge made a screechy noise every time it was opened.
I can't stand her high-pitched, screechy voice.
